column7: This bilevel Wrigleyville joint draws a strange crowd: a mix of ball-capped football fans paying full attention to the wall-size TV behind the bar and aspiring improv comics from nearby I.O. who love to rehash favorite bits and revel in their ironic choice of destination. No group pays any heed to the other, particularly when the orders of Tater Tots arrive.

column7: This Rogers Park corner bar is a lesson in—well—a neighborhood corner bar: sports on the TVs, cold beer on tap and a bunch of dudes flapping their jaws about their favorite teams. For those allergic to sports, picture windows look out over the street, and we have to admit that watching traffic and sipping a beer isn't a bad way to spend a Sunday afternoon.

column7: DePaul students, hospital staff and neighborhood urban professionals alike belly up at this combo spot. Decent bar food, foosball, pool and darts dominate downstairs at the Lion Head, where it's impossible not to find yourself facing one of the two dozen plasma and big-screen TVs. Upstairs, the Apartment sports a corny (yet comfy) club atmosphere with its beds, couches and recliners, which get plenty of use on weekends when the place is packed assholes-to-elbows with singles.

column7: We heard rumors that this late-night hookup haven gets packed with sweaty grinders around 1am, so we settled on a more mellow afternoon drink instead. Which turned out to be just fine. column7: This bar sits high above Michigan Ave, just north of the fountain in the 12th floor atrium lobby of the Ritz-Carlton. And as could be expected from a bar inside one of the city's most luxurious hotels, this place is swanksville. Chairs upholstered in soft leather and plush velvet surround ornate tables in the copper-tinted room that, after a couple martinis, you'll never want to leave.

column7: Is this an upscale tavern or a friendly neighborhood bar? The six TVs and thirtysomething dudes in baseball caps represent the latter. But then there are wooden tables topped with fresh flowers and a menu that includes cognac-soaked dates, delicious bratwurst slathered in Sierra Nevada mustard and an extensive wine list, so the jury's out. By the time you've had a few beers on the huge patio, it won't matter anyway.

column7: Expect to walk into a rambunctious and cheerful open room that oozes goodwill and Irish charm. Bartender Claire will serve your Magner's hard cider with ice, and the black and tan is poured so beautifully you'd swear you were at the Temple Bar in Dublin. A stone fireplace adds an authentic Irish cottage–like ambience, even though the menu includes some British fare. Live bands pep up the joint even more on the weekends.

column7: The best of this bar's details—a stone fireplace, stained-glass windows and the dark wood bar itself—were imported from Ireland, which should win it some kind of an award for most authentic Irish pub in Wrigleyville. Hard, wooden booths, with accompanying low tables, are barely padded; daddy longlegs will be in pain.

column7: It's more Irish than many Irish bars in the city (note the Celtic designs on the ceilings, the portraits of Irish authors on the wall), but this Edgebrook joint courts more of a U.K. crowd. As one of the first bars to sprout since the 'hood's dry years ended, it's become a hot spot for everyone in the community. In other words, don't be alarmed when you see children running around the place—they're all part of the gang.

column7: We've seen people at this dim, homey, Near North pub hang out without ever ordering a drink, but we just can't follow suit. column149: Clark Street Ale House We've seen people at this dim, homey, Near North pub hang out without ever ordering a drink, but we just can't follow suit. We envy the friendly neighbors who drop onto wooden stools just to chat up the bartender. But when we spy two dozen beers on tap—mostly domestic gems like Great Lakes Brewing Company's Elliot Ness—we feel like settling in and getting our drink on. 742 N Clark St between Superior and Chicago Sts (312-642-9253). El: Red to Chicago. Bus: 22 (24hrs), 36, 66. Mon–Fri 4pm–4am, Sat 4pm–5am; Sun 5pm–4am. Average beer: $4.
column187: Outdoor seatingExtensive beer selectionClassic Chicago spotConversation friendlyGood for over-40 crowdVideo/pinball games

column7: Fans of VH1's I Love the '80s will be in heaven surrounded by walls plastered with vintage concert tees and glass cases jam-packed with every collectible toy created in that era. During the week, there's room to take it all in, but weekends get crammed with locals rocking white belts playing pool to a DJ's mix of punk, indie rock and occasional polka. Yes, polka. After all, this is Ukrainian Village.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 50 Damen, 70 Division

column7: The floors of this converted Bucktown house shake so much from the weight of hot-footed trendsetters you'd think the place is seconds from caving in. Most of the dancing is set to a mix of hip-hop, electro and rock on the weekends (and the insanely popular first-Wednesday-of-the-month funk party called Sheer Magic), but there are plenty of nooks and crannies to sit back, relax and people-watch.
column144: El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 50 Damen, 73 Armitage

column7: One of the city's best spots for rock & roll doesn't even have a stage. Instead, this Lincoln Park favorite has one of the best jukeboxes in town for the main room (so you can play DJ Fridays and Saturdays) and hires DJs for Sunday through Thursday who know their Buzzcocks from their Bullocks. Add an insane whiskey selection, more than 200 beers (Belgian, microbrews, seasonals) and frequent free movie nights, and you have a bar to call home.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11 Lincoln/Sedgwick, 76 Diversey

column7: Thursday is fetish night and Monday it's punk rock, but pretty much any night you stumble upon this haunt for the black-clad you'll see that the freaks indeed do come out at night. column7: Young and old, dregs and misfits, singers and drunkards—all break out their best shower voice at this Ravenswood spot for karaoke seven nights a week. You're as likely to hear Young MC's "Bust a Move" as you are Sinatra's "It Was a Very Good Year." The same kind of juxtaposition puts watermelon shots next to Manhattans on the weekly specials board. Deee-lish.

column7: This place claims it serves "Chicago's best Bloody Mary," and as famed pitcher Dizzy Dean said, "It ain't braggin' if you can back it up." The Big Downtown can. Said drink comes with a theatrical garnish of a leafy stalk of celery, pickled asparagus spear and haricot vert, a jumbo olive and a sweet gherkin. The rim is powdered with celery salt, and the secret spicy tomato mix blends nicely with top-shelf vodka. Martinis are tasty, too, but could be shaken longer to add more chill. The decor is reminiscent of a classy train dining car, with dark wood, crisp white linens, and subdued lighting illuminating black-and-white photos of Chicago jazz and blues musicians.
column92: Palmer House Hilton, 124 S Wabash Ave
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams

column7: Just off the U. of C. campus, Jimmy's (as it's affectionately called by those in the know, after dearly departed original owner Jimmy Wilson) is the favored spot for the scholars to rub elbows with undergrads and working-class neighborhood regulars. Cheap burgers are washed down with even cheaper beer and the air is thick with decades worth of smoke.

column7: Whether it's lunchtime or late at night, this steak-and-a-beer standby captures a classic Chicago feel in a far more subtle manner than most. It could be the bartender with his slick vest and tie or the towering walls of signed photos from satisfied Chicago sports and entertainment celebs. But we like to think that classicness is mainly due to the straight-talking clientele that likes its whiskey on the rocks and its ties loose.

column7: This forgotten Polish bar is usually so empty that shortly after arriving you'll feel like you and your friends own the place. Bask in your uncontested reign—save for one or two quiet barflies—over the pool table and digital juke, and enjoy the bartender's full attention. And although we got a puzzled look when we asked for a PBR, the small selection of tasty Polish beers made us forgive and (eventually) forget.

column7: Sarge did two tours in Vietnam, and this Rogers Park bar, which he's owned for more than 17 years, is a shrine to his Marine Corps roots. He's plastered military pictures, flak jackets, packs and other paraphernalia on the walls, while camouflage netting hangs from the ceiling and above the pool table. After buying you a shot of "jungle juice," Sarge will pull up a stool and fill your ear with stories about chasing "Charlies" and keeping out the Rogers Park riffraff. Semper fi!

column7: As its name implies (and its location next to the El tracks underscores), the feel here is that of a bar inside a Depression-era train station. Stained-glass ceiling lights emit an amber glow; fringe dangles from the faux smoke-stained lampshades; and small black-and-white ceramic tiles line the floor. But the centerpiece—despite the prevalence of flat-screen TVs and crazy-drunk locals on weekends—is the piano that sits on a round stage behind the long front bar.

column7: Even at 10am, you'll find a loyal clientele of grizzled late-shifters raising glasses of Old Style to making it through a night at the factory, buying cigarettes and Snickers from the same vending machine, and then taking a sixer to go. column7: Max is actually a woman (Maxine), and her Uptown establishment is a seminar in Dive Bar 101: The pours are dangerously strong, the drinks are ridiculously cheap, the bartenders are gloriously mulleted, and the regulars are, uh, very regular. column7: It's tough to get more authentic than this Polish bar, where if there's not a soccer game on, then surely the jukebox is playing some ditty from the homeland. And besides, really cheap beer, ping-pong and pool are things every ethnicity can embrace.

column7: The Hard Rock Hotel has remodeled its old bar, Base, and rechristened it ROCKS. So what has changed? Inasmuch, also expect a tourist mom in a hot-pink T-shirt barrels through pushing a ginormous stroller. But as the night wears on, the crowd gets hipper, the beats get louder and the tourists—they get some sleep.

But with only three TV screens, this is a sports bar of a different kind—that is, it's a bar where you can grab a booth with your friends and actually hear yourselves as you talk about the game or (and this is the truly different part) anything else.

column7: This low-key lounge boasts "the best sangria in town," and while we wouldn't go that far, we do think their $15 pitchers of red and white are a good antidote for a bad day at work ($2 burgers and fries on Mondays and $2.50 Coronas on Tuesdays don't hurt, either). This spot is especially good for those who have experienced sports bar fatigue: Here, there's not a single game in sight.

column7: Step inside this hangout and you'll be bombarded with music, video art and two levels of clubby hipsters packed in for celebrity DJs. If it's all a bit too much, escape to the sidewalk patio for people-watching and $15 liters of Absolut Italian ice lemonades or unlimited mimosas for $18. The latter includes a flatbread appetizer, good for soaking up some of that slosh-talk that could get you in trouble.

column7: One can only assume the name refers to petite bartender Eva, the sole blond at this working-class neighborhood joint. The primarily male clientele ranges from undershirt-clad young Latinos playing pool to an elderly gentleman with his walker parked next to the bar. Order an Okocim and Eva will top it off Polish-style with a shot of sour-cherry syrup and a straw, and serve up some fresh popcorn alongside.

column7: The address is different (the original location was a few blocks east), but the booking policy remains the same at this pioneering venue and informal showcase for members of Chicago's trailblazing Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians. column7: Something doesn't add up: If every other Lincoln Avenue pub is packed sweaty ass to sweaty crotch, why is it that Sterch's pulls in only a handful of drinkers? It must suck, right? Well, given this venerable bar (in its forties) is inviting to newbies, loyal to its regulars (old photos on the wall, house bowling leagues, etc.) and plenty spacious for the two to mingle, that's probably not the case. Just be thankful this friendly drinking relic is still around.

But you didn't actually come here for the food, did you?

column7: Chaise is both restaurant and lounge, and it hawks martinis as vehemently as it does dishes such as an autumn salad of parsnips and Asian pears; sweet-potato latkes; and beef short rib in red wine jus. But it's the rooftop deck (covered in a tent in chillier months) and alfresco patio that steal the show—at least for those looking to rub elbows with Miami Beach wanna-bes.
column149: Chaise Lounge Chaise is both restaurant and lounge, and it hawks martinis as vehemently as it does dishes such as an autumn salad of parsnips and Asian pears; sweet-potato latkes; and beef short rib in red wine jus. column7: Like a gay Cheers, everybody knows everybody's name here. A long winding bar, amber lighting, dark wood and green leather booths make for a tavern-y spot to sip one of the gajillion beers or two dozen wines by the glass. TVs show sports, but older locals are focused on their grilled chicken Caesars, and the lesbians are too busy flirting to notice.

column7: Locals descend upon "The Dunne's" from their condos in Roscoe Village's Pencil Factory, soaking up the sports theme dominated by support for Boston College and Dayton. Golden Tee Live is a big source of entertainment, and the camaraderie among the regulars would make Finley Peter Dunne (columnist for the Chicago Evening Post in the late 1800s) proud.

column7: The selling point here is the big $2 fishbowl schooners of MGD, the big draw for the lunchtime crowd of blue-collar types drinking the day's meal. As one regular puts it: "No jukebox, no pool, no video games, no food—no nuthin' but drinks." This is clearly not the place to order flaming rum punch; however, if you want to take some "packaged goods" with you, a liquor store is attached. But bring cash: A wood carving of a man being lynched has a caption that reads, "This man asked for credit."

column7: This place is primarily a restaurant, but we like just stopping in for a Peroni at the bar. You'll probably rub elbows with old Italian locals who remember Chinatown before it was Chinatown. The joint's been around since '33, and the regulars whose mugs hang from the ceiling are long gone, but they're immortalized in a dusty photo hanging behind the bar. Hungry? Hearty pastas or sausage and peppers will work.

column7: There's nothing particularly inventive about this corner tap, both levels of which are usually inhabited by your run-of-the-mill, shaggy-haired, middle-aged whiskey sippers—nothing, that is, unless you're here on a Friday night. column7: There's a big sign on the wall here with a rendering of Wrigley Field that reads: "Believe or leave." (That is, as long as the Cubs are winning.)

column7: So you're wondering how a sports bar with a crowd of screaming coeds and an impressive list of drinkable "bombs" (when Jäger alone just won't cut it anymore) found its way into Bucktown. But you're sucking down the 32-oz schooners like they're holy water and hogging the pool table, so the frat-mentality invasion can't be all that bad. Winter means you can trade Blue Bombs for a Hot Apple Cider, Hot Toddie or Rumplestillsken (Rumple Minze and hot chocolate), and the bar also now serves pizzas ($11.50–$17).

column7: We're not complaining about $1.25 drafts of MGD and Lite in this cozy little barit's just that, for a place called "Brewery," you'd think the beer selection would be a little more broad. But never mind that. With Sinatra and Tony Bennett crooning away and a pack of serious pool players huddled around the pool table, there's plenty to distract you from the lackluster beer selection. You must be 25 to enter, and the ID checking is nothing short of fanatical. But if you're old enough, stop by on October 28th for a Chili Cook-off that should be rather spirited, as several regulars have the beans to claim that their homemade recipes score highest on the chili-o-meter.

column7: Brudder is Hawaiian for "hang loose," and this isn't a bad place to do exactly that, especially if you're sports-inclined. The bar is a hop, skip and drive down Addison from Wrigley, so you can count on Cubs games being broadcast on all eight TVs. There's a separate room for the pool table, which gets plenty of use with the dough saved on dollar drafts of PBR and Old Style.

column7: This teeny taproom is a good stone's throw from the hustle and muscle of Halsted Street's rowdy boy bars—and that's just the way this clientele likes it. Plenty of ladies hang here until the midnight hour, but the boys crash the party shortly thereafter, creating one of the few truly mixed queer scenes in the city. Don't let superfox bartender Karen Holden give you a hard time; she's secretly a softie.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 36, 77

column7: The rumble of the train drowns out your conversation in the beer garden every five minutes, but that's a small price to pay for a laid-back day sipping beer in the sun. Servers are attentive, and the crowd outside is pretty chill—the only shit-talking going on is at the Golden Tee or at the pool table. That is until the rest of the neighborhood's bars close at 2 and the line outside waiting to get in gets unruly.

column7: True dive bars are a rarity in this high-rent, hotel and wine bar–dominated section of River North, and that's exactly what makes this Greek-owned beer-and-gyro joint a gem. Inside, 50-year-old union laborers with leathery skin, gold necklaces and curly chest hair sip domestics and shoot pool beside their younger blond wives, while the Croatian bartender regales her customers with stories about Christmas back home.

column7: Small touches of Irish bric-a-brac—a leprechaun napkin holder and an erin go bragh flag—are the only concessions to the Old Sod. Otherwise, this shot-and-beer tap room is heavy on local sports teams past and present, with its framed pics of faded Bears heroes. Beer selections are standard American brews, like Sam Adams and Bud longnecks, but still, it's an accommodating 18-seat bar and a good dark room to duck into when it's blazing hot outside.

column7: Is it a gay bar? Is it straight? Do we care? column7: The menu boasts 30 martinis, but don't be surprised when the bartender thumbs through Mr. Boston's crib sheets to concoct them. The "Mag Mile Manhattan" features smoky and silky 18-year-old Elijah Craig bourbon, but beware the heavy-handed buzzkill of sweet vermouth. More than two-dozen professional pool tables fill the bilevel space, and the jukebox is packed with crooners—Sinatra, Dino and Darin—lending an old-school vibe.
column60: Mon–Fri 11am–2am; Sat 5pm–3am; Sun 5pm–2am (closed Sun during summer)

column7: This Rogers Park cantina offers a little Tijuana flavor right here in the Windy City. The jukebox cranks out Mexican music that couples shuffle along to, but if dancing isn't your thing, there's a pool table and Mexican soap operas on the television to entertain. Even cans of Bud come with a lime slice, adding to the overall flavor of both the beer and the bar.

column7: The once-divey Ukie Village DJ bar has been reborn as a compact, high-design club in Wicker Park. The Suhail-conceived concrete bar contrasts with a glowing red ceiling panel, and removable modular seating means more dance space for bigger gigs. The owners (also of SmallBar) have kept the diverse roster of resident DJs. The style upgrade doesn't mean a neglected beer list: Look for more than a dozen boutique labels on the bottle list.

column7: It's not that this old Bucktown standby feels like somebody's living room; it's that it basically is one. It's her second home, and after a few minutes chatting with her over a cheap bottle of beer, it starts feeling like yours, too.

column7: Three years after relocating to River North, this sleek, grown-up bar remains Champagne central. But recent additions from wine director W. Craig Cooper make it just as fine a destination for a sparkling cocktail (the Chute de Shooni, made with Calvados and five-spice; the Avenue A, a mix of bourbon, cava and Giottine Cherry) or a not-so-sparkling craft beer (La Chouffe Golden Ale, North Coast's Scrimshaw Pilsner, Bell's Porter).
column149: Pops for Champagne Three years after relocating to River North, this sleek, grown-up bar remains Champagne central. But recent additions from wine director W. Craig Cooper make it just as fine a destination for a sparkling cocktail (the Chute de Shooni, made with Calvados and five-spice; the Avenue A, a mix of bourbon, cava and Giottine Cherry) or a not-so-sparkling craft beer (La Chouffe Golden Ale, North Coast's Scrimshaw Pilsner, Bell's Porter). 601 N State St at Ohio St (312-266-7677). El: Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 36, 65. Sun–Fri 3pm–2am; Sat 1pm–2am. Average glass of wine: $15.

column7: Though the name is a head-scratcher, this no-frills pub is a friendly Jefferson Park retreat. A faded mural promises 101 beers, but even though that number has dwindled to a modest 15, the regulars—middle-aged dudes and their frosted-hair babes—probably couldn't care less. The trees in the adjacent beer garden don't bear any ham, but they will make for a shady spot come summertime.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81 (24hrs), 85

column7: This modest Northwest Side shot-and-beer joint takes its name from the first capital of Poland—an indicator of the clientele and serving staff. Vodka's big here, and you can get a generous ice-cold pour for $3.25 and pretend it's a very dry martini (vermouth is overrated anyway). There's a full-color photo of Polish hero and icon Pope John Paul II on the back bar, several Elvis CDs on the jukebox and an old-fashioned cigarette machine dispensing smokes at retro prices.

column7: Most of the guys who go to this sporty, sceney homage to stainless steel don't seem to care what the food tastes like—it's more of a tits and beer thing for them. But if they'd pay attention, they'd find that most of the menu is much better than the chewy, cardboardish pizzas. As counter-intuitive as it may seem, the antibar food is where the gems are, like the mildly spicy braised lamb lettuce wraps and the perfectly golden roasted chicken.

column7: West Loop residents have this comfy place to escape their condos, lofts and loft-condos. column7: This welcoming neighborhood joint has added a whole new food menu to its novella-size beer list. The burgers are now a costar here—solid but not too dense, dressed in surprisingly fresh ingredients. The Hell Fire's got melted pepper-jack cheese, crisp jalapeños and a rich Sriracha aioli that satisfies a spice craving without overwhelming the meat. Sweet potato fries might be ubiquitous, but they rarely taste as fresh as these—thick and slightly sweet, great with the peppery burger and a refreshing white ale.

column7: Neighborhood bars are as rampant as drunks in Wrigleyville, right? So why make this one your new spot? Because your hoodie doesn't have exposed wood beams and brick walls, wrought-iron chandeliers, or a downstairs lounge with leather banquettes and a black-felt pool table. The menu alone, which offers a good selection of nicely presented salads, sandwiches and steaks, is well worth becoming a regular.

column7: A bistro in France it ain't, but curiously enough, this tidy, dark dive takes a few traditions from across the Atlantic. The larger-than-life posters of De Niro on the wall, however, are completely American.

You'll recognize the same Irish-English-pub vibe from up north, and you may spy a frat rat, but generally the crowd—like the bookish, lofty-artsy neighborhood—is definitely mixed, especially when it comes to baseball loyalties.

column7: A surprising number of locals hang at this hotel bar in the Fairmont Chicago, thanks to its hip-but-not-trying-too-hard atmosphere. Unlike so many bars, there are plenty of comfy places to sit: the tiny tables in the middle of the room, on comfy bar stools or in leather booths. Try the pumpkin nog, a secret (by request only) holiday elixir designed to help numb the pain of family get-togethers.

column7: If you're wondering what sets this friendly West Loop bar and grill apart from every other pub that's packed tightly with graduate- and law-school types, it's the selection of 40 draught beers (including three tasty styles from our Hoosier faves Three Floyds). column7: Across the street from the Jefferson Park CTA station, this wood-paneled neighborhood joint seems like the perfect opportunity for a quick drink while waiting for your bus to arrive. But be careful: When the Bears game is on, that sweet bartender is flirting with you and one Johnny Cash tune gets played after another, it's impossible not to get sucked in. You might miss not just your bus, but the rest of your day, too.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81, 85, 91

column7: Modeled after the more-than-a-century-old bar in Manhattan, this River North watering hole channels old-school service and style (read: lots of mahogany, more than 50 bottles of Scotch and polite bartenders). column7: Criticism of our country probably isn't wise inside these wood-paneled, firehouse-themed walls. With all the pro-America posters and flags, there's more patriotism in here than in the White House. Join the crowd of old firemen on a Sunday, when they usually grill outside. No one will understand your "commie talk" if you've got a brat stuffed in your mouth.

column7: Because it's on the outer edge of Madison Street, beyond the throng of deafening bro bars, this warm, inviting place has a little more freedom to be classy. Sure, it's still an Irish pub, but that has less to do with shamrocks than Smithwick's and fish and chips. Flickering candles line the dark-wood bar, which sports a full wine rack and a respectable selection of bottled microbrews. There's also a conversation-friendly outdoor patio with six umbrella-topped tables.

column7: This "Sox Side" Bridgeport dive is about as polar opposite from a Cubby bar as it gets; pre-game revelry typically consists of a couple of dusty-jeans locals holding a burping contest while regaling each other with slurred jokes. column7: There's no better place to cheer on your team than this down-home, blue-collar institution that's been serving up cold ones since 1881. Arrive at least a half hour before game time if you're planning on eating—and you should definitely plan on eating. Just-like-Mom-made classics include crispy pork tenderloin smothered in perfect pan gravy and greaseless fried chicken. Add doting servers, cheap beer and a living room–like atmosphere, and you've got the best sports experience short of front-row tickets.

column7: Pearls? Check. Cigarettes? Check. Bright pink lipstick? Check. All of owner Nelly's essentials are in order and she's officially open for business. Expect handsome, loaded Romanian imports chowing down on the earthy cuisine of Romania: platters of mititei (grilled sausages); fried kraut with bits of bacon fat; heaping bowls of polenta with feta; and pan-fried chicken wings. Other than weekends when there's live music or anytime a soccer game's on, it's likely to be just you and Nelly, the queen of amaretto stone sours.

column7: It's all old-world charm at this "Downtown Bar with a Neighborhood Atmosphere," even if it took raiding grandma's attic to pull it off. Somehow faded leopard carpeting, mismatched Tiffany-style lamps and a cash register from 1912 all gel together. Grab a stool at the bar or sprawl out at one of the many open booths. Either way, you'll be looking at the same faces night after night; that is, if you can see them behind the sloppy ribs they're scarfing.

column7: On the weekends, this polished Roscoe Village hangout is filled with local singles awkwardly trying to get some, and it's sort of like watching a too-good-to-be-true episode of Blind Date. Sampling the extensive list of Irish beers and whiskeys is best done in the back—a cool, open space with couches, a fireplace and old-school board games.

column7: We are in love with Katerina. Like any good lover, she keeps us infatuated: her signature cocktails like the sour cherry martini, the eclectic roster of bands (jazz, funk, traditional Greek), the candlelit space, and her Southern European menu (calamari, sautéed shrimp, spanokopita). In between checking IDs and pouring cocktails, it's common for Katerina to quip that "cigarettes make your breasts firmer" or break into song and croon for the love-struck regulars.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, X80

column7: Situated in the Allegro Hotel, which itself is situated next to the Palace Theater, Encore attracts a clientele of tourists, more tourists and theater fans. Settle into one of the booths, and you should be able to suss out who falls into which category. That is, until you start in on one of the strong, neon martinis. In which case you won't even know which category you fall into anymore.

column7: This bar certainly leans toward frat-tastic, but its patrons seem oddly subdued. column7: Cheap beer fast. What's not to like about that? As its name suggests, Cans serves canned beer, nearly three dozen varieties. If Greek (aka frat talk) ain't your speak, the pool table (one of Bucktown's best) and the '80s soundtrack are draws.

column7: A surprising number of locals hang at this hotel bar in the Fairmont Chicago thanks to its hip-but-not-trying-too-hard atmosphere. Unlike so many bars, there are plenty of comfy places to sit: the tiny tables in the middle of the room, on bar stools with backs on them or in leather booths. Try the pumpkin nog, a secret (request-only) holiday exilir design to help numb the pain of family get-togethers.

column7: After closing for a few months, O Lounge has relocated from its former Lakeview digs to another, less-occupied Lakeview corner. The music gets our hips moving, but the dance floor is small and awkwardly shaped (due to stairs smack-dab in the middle). Pricey cocktails are the drink of choice, but come in plastic, er, glasses. The glowing platform, for the most liquid-courageous of dancers, looks like a giant version of the memory game Simon. In the end, this is a bar with a weak club facade—but judging by the massive line outside, for some, that might be enough.

column7: Named after the owner's hometown in Mexico, this informal cantina has a homey feel—an aunt makes tamales on holidays and snacks on weekends. There's Spanish music on the jukebox, and Tecates are three bucks a pop. Just don't try anything too fancy (they're often out of margarita mix), and make like the regulars—they seem quite happy with their cerveza frias and tequila with a side of Squirt.

column7: It's pronounced "poo-cheen still" (Gaelic for "moonshine"), but take the bartenders' cue and call it "the Stil." This Rogers Park pub is the antithesis of its former inhabitant, Charmers, the city's oldest, grittiest and emptiest gay bar: It's bright and bustling, there's often live music and friendly bartenders pour a proper Guinness. Rest assured, nostalgists: Charmers' beautiful Art Deco bar remains intact.

column7: Javier Haro is named after the capital of Spain's celebrated wine region Rioja. so it's only natural that he would open a Spanish restaurant. Aiming for authenticity—and hoping to distinguish itself from every other tapas joint in the city—the restaurant will serve its wine in porróns, a traditional glass bottle used to pour wine into your mouth, and chef Greg Cannon will focus on pinxtos, shareable small plates that are as common in Basque bars as peanuts are here.

column7: This year-old sports spot is just blocks away from Wrigley Field, but we think the view of the Cubs is better from the bar. Movie-size projections of the games flicker behind the surprisingly good lineup of liquor, getting you a lot closer to the action than those scalped tickets will. And the food here-Palermo's pizza-beats Wrigley's hot dogs any day.

column7: The corner where this North Center tap sits has been a neighborhood hot spot since Prohibition: The former Schulien's featured a basement speakeasy and a house magician. The 'hood has changed—today's O'Donovan's operates as a laid-back hangout for younger couples and small groups—but the tableside magic shows (and the occasional balloon sculptist) remain on weekends. Escape the crowds in the tucked-away beer garden, heated and enclosed in the winter.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 80, X80

column7: Underneath a highway and inside a dark, unmarked storefront isn't the first place you'd look for kids and dogs. But when a bar opens at 7am, its patrons—a diverse mix of guys (yeah, they're pretty much all guys) from the neighborhood who work all hours of the night—tend to get pretty comfortable, stopping in for a beer (all bottles, no taps) regardless of what they've got with them.

column7: When Boystown's minibar opened in 2005 as a Lilliputian lounge with classy cocktails, its diminutive size seemed ideally suited to late-night conversing and canoodling. But in 2007, it purchased the space next door, and earlier this year, it expanded yet again. Now, minibar is really anything but—and it has the Las Vegas nightclub vibe to prove it. Chef Brian Merel tries to compensate for the lack of dining-room vibe with a menu of artful, upscale comfort foodbut in Boystown, the food rarely comes first.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: Picture a large rectangular bar surrounded by patrons guzzling down Hamm's beer and shots of Old Grand Dad. It's the middle of the day, and a guy keeps shouting out, "A cowboy's life is the fucking life for me!" while nearby a boozy couple slow dances to oldies on the jukebox. It may look like an ordinary Chicago house on the outside, but in here, bathed in neon beer signs, it's dive city.

column7: We're not sure how to peg this place. At times it feels like a neighborhood bar, yet with a loungey vibe. Factor in the pool table and cheap drinks, and you have an ambitious hole in the wall. Bands play weekends, so maybe it's really a live music venue. And every once in a while the goth tribe is also known to gather here for industrial and darkwave parties. Oh well. Whatever this place is, it certainly has something for everyone.

column7: Yes, the rumors are true: To get into this old-timey watering hole, Johnny has to buzz you in. Better still, if the longtime proprietor digs talking to you, he'll keep the beer flowing past closing time.

column7: People go to other diners for greasy bacon and eggs, fatty hamburgers and limp french fries. But they come to this one, a tiny charming room whose walls are covered with '50s-era nostalgia, for food they can watch being made to order in the open kitchen. Sitting at the long counter, you can witness the eggs being cracked for your fluffy omelette, the batter being stirred for your thin and airy pancakes, and, if you're there on the weekend, the rich, sausage-studded gravy being spooned over dense, buttery biscuits. But the kitchen staff can see you, too, so try to control yourself while stuffing it all into your mouth.

column7: First impressions are not this spot's strong suit. column7: Thanks to a metal-clad exterior that sticks out like a Clockwork Orange thumb in this ho-hum stretch of west Belmont Central, this hot, young Polish haunt is impossible to miss. Less Weed Street nightclub and more Exit metal dude hangout, the bar has an interior covered with intricate, high-quality metalwork from a local Polish artist. Add pool and foosball tables, a great jukebox and cheap drinks, and you might just start checking out real estate in the area.

column7: At first glance, this 60-year-old establishment seems cast from the same mold as every other neighborhood Irish pub. After all, it has about a dozen Irish whiskeys, an antique wooden bar and photos of the South Side from the early 1900s hanging on its walls. It's the theme nights that separate this spot from the rest of the Notre Dame flag–waving pack. Our favorites are Sundays (free hotdogs from noon to 6pm), Mondays ("party with your pooch") and Tuesdays (board games).

column7: Two slick rooms awash in shiny mirrored tile and video art and a clientele of only the richest, prettiest Chicagoans. Recently, the place got a face-lift from a new menu of Kobe corn dogs, escargot fritters and oyster shooters (courtesy of Primehouse chef Rick Gresh) and from a new installation by local artist Brian Graves.

column7: Around the corner from Division Street's jack-ass bar scene is this cozy one-room saloon tucked inside the Canterbury Court Hotel. Singles, socialites, cigar smokers and even sexagenarians pack themselves in on busy weekends. The zebra theme is a bit reckless, but distinctive. The ultrared lighting, on the other hand, makes you wonder if students from the Art Institute are going to emerge from behind the bar with developed film. A nightly piano player keeps the Zebra refreshingly unhip with old-school faves like "Do You Know the Way to San Jose."

column7: An artery-clogging breakfast can be found at any greasy spoon, but this South Loop outpost of the Billy Goat (brighter and not as historically charming as the original) specializes in slinging drinks alongside plates of steak and eggs. Some of Chicago's harder-hustling disco and electro DJs man the booth. 839 W Fulton Mkt between Green and Peoria Sts (312-733-2222). El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 56, 65. Tue 10pm–2am; Fri 9pm–2am; Sat 9pm–3am. Average cocktail: $8.

column7: With its gaudy mishmash of faux Frank Lloyd Wright stained glass, wood paneling and crumbling Euro-style urinals, this corner tavern seems a likely candidate for Extreme Makeover: Bar Edition. Otherwise, this is a perfectly likable corner tavern with a stellar jukebox where single women sip Cosmos out of frosted martini glasses while old men huddle in the corner swilling beer and whiskey.

column7: This Logan Square hangout began life as a coffeehouse, but has emerged in recent years as a hip live music venue for emerging artists (i.e., twentysomethings with keyboards). column7: Finding an empty chair on Southport on a Saturday night can be like trying to find free parking around Wrigley Field. When you arrive here at 10pm you'll think you're out of luck again. But edge past the crowd hanging out at the dark wood bar, and you'll very possibly find empty tables, empty chairs and several empty beer glasses from the person who got drunk here before you.

column7: Thank your lucky stars if you roll into this no-frills, blue-collar Irish pub on a night the endless fount of entertainment known as Crazy Kerry is slinging drinks. column7: With its three distinct barrooms, this Uptown oasis is custom-made for the indecisive patron. An imposing wine rack and wafting surf-and-turf scents give the ground floor an air of fine dining. But we recommend heading upstairs for all the fun: Mondays' martini and a manicure in the lounge, Thursdays' improv competition, and Fridays' '80s-themed burlesque revue.

column7: If the heavy weekend traffic of thirtysomethings at Huettenbar ain't your thing, check out this less refined German spot just down the block. The bare-bones setting makes for a laid-back, chatty evening of drinking drafts of Konig Ludwig or Warsteiner Dunkel. True, the decorative Christmas lights and homemade Jäger bombs $6 sign scream tackiness, but there's something refreshing about a place that looks like it hasn't changed since 1975.

column7: Thanks to proprietor and activist Chuck Renslow and competitions like International Mr. Leather (which is headquartered here), fetish bars enjoy a pretty mainstream status. That doesn't mean this one is for the faint of heart. The front room is dimly lit with Tom of Finland–esque artwork (i.e., well-endowed dudes in various erotic poses) while a dress-code enforced backroom is so dimly lit we can only describe it as dungeonesque.

column7: British ales and imported Scotches aren't the only spirits served up at this cozy little slice of London; ghost stories are as commonly dished out (as are baskets brimming with fish and chips). If you ask nicely, the pub's silver-tongued owner, Colin Cordwell, might even break from carefully eyeing DePaul students' IDs to brag about all the spooked former employees of his supposedly haunted haunt.

column7: Deutschland certainly takes a lot of pride in its beer. So before you get schnitzel-faced at this friendly German restaurant in North Center, sample the dozen or so ales and lagers on tap. If you don't know your Weizen from your Dunkel, the cute, German-accented waitresses are happy to make recommendations. Consult a nearby German-American family on the topic and you'll be singing "Deutschland über alles" in no time.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 80

column7: If you think having a dive bar in Naperville is impossible, this spot just off the railroad tracks should change your mind. For the last 20 years, Orazio has been serving cheap brew and grub with a blue-collar, no-nonsense attitude. In this posh 'burb, the tacky Christmas lights, free popcorn, pitchers and Golden Tee won us over.

column7: Believe it or not, the cult item on this pubbish menu is not fried, greasy or full of cheese—it's the salads. The $5 salad special on Tuesday nights (stereotypically dubbed "girls' night out") has made the big bowls of greens topped with avocado and portobello mushroom the hottest dish on the block. But bar-food aficionados need not worry: A trio of soft pretzels (two of which are filled, respectively, with marinara sauce and mozzarella) and the deep-fried Reuben rolls (a heart attack waiting to happen) fill that niche nicely. We found the pulled-pork sandwich way too sweet, however, so skip it and satisfy your sweet tooth with the warm, gooey skillet cookie.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 74

column7: The thin-crust pizza at this sporty bar—which masquerades as a pizza parlor—is respectably flavorful, but for the residents of the surrounding apartment buildings, it's just a prelude to other things. And by "other things" we mean what happens after people hang out on a breezy flower-lined sidewalk patio for hours drinking pitcher after pitcher of cheap beer only to wonder, "What's your place look like?"

column7: Every family has a creepy uncle, and we just found his hangout. Part liquor store, part bar, this oddly lit (fluorescent and incandescent lights?), worn-out corner tap has managed to rope in a small but loyal contingent of whiskery, sunken-faced older men. Some of them come to smoke hands-free and pump money into the Cherry Masters game, while the other smarmy fellers shoot pool waiting to ogle the one unfortunate woman who accidentally walks in here once a decade.

column7: Not feeling Subterranean's music for the night? Can't take the hipper-than-thou crowd at Rainbo? Prefer a place less clubbier than Debonair? Well, then head to this low-key sanctuary in the oft-pretentious Milwaukee-North-Damen intersection. No one's trying to out-cool anyone here (though late at night, they're definitely trying to pick each other up), so feel free to strike up a conversation with a stranger over some tasty late-night bar eats, served till 3am.

column7: Of all the neighborhood bars trying to make rambling Ashland Avenue feel more homey, this gem is among the homiest. Art Deco touches abound, live music kicks up a little dust on the weekends and the mood is consistently upbeat, chatty and sociable. The twenty/thirtysomething regulars live on the cusp—they're not quite Lakeview and not quite Ravenswood, which suits us just fine.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, X9, 80, X80

column7: The menu is more comfort-food than "gastropub," but with prices like this we're not inclined to let semantics get in the way. Tiny pulled-pork sandwiches (called, in overly cute fashion, "BBites") are tender and sweet; bacon-wrapped trout is crispy and flavored with sage; and the bar steak, while a little plain, is flavorful and juicy (just ignore those limp fries). Beer is pushed as the drink of choice here, but the real draw is the wine list, which has 25 bottles—not one of which exceeds $30.

column7: Though the sign outside Uptown's newest bar and grill gets the vintage, '40s-ish feeling just right, you might want to keep your zoot suit at home: Inside, Rihana is singing about um-ber-ellas and martinis are made with pomegranate juice. Skip the Reuben bites and goat cheese appetizer (the goat cheese, which claims to be seasoned with harissa, is particularly disappointing). Instead, head straight for the braised pork belly Cuban sandwich, the rich meat mingling with vinegary pickles to great success, or the chicken fried steak, which arrives topped with a thick gravy that's hard to stop eating (even though it's clear that if you don't stop soon, it's going to kill you).

column149: Relax Lounge While this West Town bar is marketed as a hipster rock club, the slick design is much more West Elm than CBGB. But we're not complaining; it turns out that partying like older, more affluent and slightly more sophisticated rock veterans is just as fun. Plus, anybody who favors seared duck over DJs can head over any Thursday night for a pop-up three-course dinner from Top Chef Dale Levitski. 1450 W Chicago Ave between Bishop St and Greenview Ave (312-666-6006). El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66. Tue–Fri 6pm–2am; Sat 7pm–3am. Average beer: $6.
column187: Food servedLive bands

column7: This inconspicuous bar is equal parts after-work dive and Antiques Roadshow. Amid dusty knickknacks and bric-a-brac, the family who runs the place will pour you a stiff drink and then try to sell you a Civil War–era revolver, a set of buffalo-themed shot glasses or anything else lying around—anything except for the patriarch's wall-mounted marlin and the Hamm's sign hanging out front.
column149: Archie's This inconspicuous bar is equal parts after-work dive and Antiques Roadshow. Bus: 49 Western (24hrs), 66 Chicago. 11am–2am. Average beer: $3.

column7: Although the redesign of the former Heaven on Seven into a traditional German beer hall is respectable, the fratesque Wrigleyville clientele works against its authenticity. There was plenty of imported Hofbrau to fill our mugs, but we couldn't shake the feeling we were on the abandoned set of The Man Show. If you're looking a spot to escape those Kimmel-esque "ziggy zaggy" chants, we'd recommend the more tolerable "biergarten."

column7: If you're having a severe case of Wrigleyville sports bar déjà vu, this place won't cure what ails you. But if you're near the Friendly Confines and just looking for an exponentially more laid-back version of Hi-Tops, this is your place. The large, dimly lit, concrete-and-tile space may not be any more comfortable, but the slightly older, less annoyingly boisterous crowd is more interested in the score of the game than scoring.

column7: There's nothing really special about this Wrigleyville spot, but the daily deals draw us in like flies. With $1 domestic drafts on Mondays and $1 burgers on Thursdays (and plenty of other specials in between), it's no wonder why this place is always packed.

column7: Owner Malcolm Molloy has that fresh-off-the-boat brogue that could charm the pants off your own mother. But please don't take this for one of your run-of-the-mill McIrish pubs. Bluegrass bands pluck away and locals might lift a Cosmo just as soon as a pint. So compared with most other pubs laying claim to the Emerald Isle, it's a sea of tranquility.

column7: Though old George has been bellying up to the big bar in the sky for decades, his small tavern survives untouched, save the digital juke. Within this true dive's smoke-stained, wood-paneled walls, the beer's mostly canned, and on-tap suds are limited to Bud and Bud Light. Not exactly what we would call selection, but the construction crews seem to like it just fine.

column7: Yes, this is really happening: You're sitting in a cheesy lounge named after the Three's Company hangout, on ugly office furniture, and you're listening to the theme from The Love Boat. The televisions really are showing programs (and commercials) from the early '80s, and your drink truly is called the "Tony Danza Extravaganza." We know, we know—it feels like you're in some bad Reagan-era sitcoms. But you're not. You're simply in a bar dedicated to them.

The Zen monastery–inspired decor makes a chic backdrop, but a good portion of the club is often given over to VIP areas.

column7: River North's Buzz is a bit of a chameleon, catering to salsa, house and hip-hop crowds on almost every day of the week. Salsa rules on Wednesdays and Sundays, and a promoter caters to a predominantly Asian crew of nightclubbers on Fridays for a blend of house and hip-hop. But because it's within walking distance to the other River North hot spots, there's an eclectic mix of partyers letting loose.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 156

column7: Looking for an after-hours hetero hookup? When Wrigleyville's bars begin to close, every inch of this cavernous, woody space attached to 1000 Liquors teems with an eager twentysomething crowd looking to maintain a domestic-beer buzz, down a couple $1 Jell-O shots (Fridays and Saturdays) and make that last-ditch effort to take home a hottie. Big City's rowdy rep belies its late-night kitchen that serves better-than-average bar fare till 3am.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77

Celeb-connected promotions alternate with visits from big-name electronic stars.

column7: Just off of one of the busiest intersections in hipland, this multilevel venue has survived a few noise violations to become more relevant than ever. The upstairs is devoted to a live stage (viewable from a third-floor balcony), which features indie, garage, hip-hop and jammy acts nightly. The downstairs bar serves as a cozy dance den for locals to let loose. The weekly lineup includes hip-hop, reggae and some very fine mod and soul nights.

DJs typically spin pop-dance mixes and club favorites, and weekends throb with the action of big spenders.

column7: This slick, modern, multilevel Euro-style club in River North opened to much fanfare in 2004 and has kept clubbers busy ever since. Touring big-name DJs in techno and progressive house usually play Friday nights with residents spinning house and electro on Saturdays.

column7: Just a few years ago, this joint was raver HQ, but it's since been transformed several times over. Upstairs, DJs accompanied by live percussion and tantalizing platformed dancers create a seductive if familiar playlist of hip-hop grinders.

column7: You can't judge a bar by its chipped glass brick veneer. Inside what seems like a total dive, you'll be pleasantly surprised to find a clean, well-lit and friendly place. The barkeep in a cowgirl getup recently was kind enough to call the wife of a regular from Derry, Ireland, to come scoop up her sauced old man. Rows of aged look-alikes in flannel shirts huddle around Old Styles, while younger dudes play video games and foosball. Choose from the usual drafts or go for the damn fine Bloody Mary.

column7: It may not be as high up as other rooftop hotel bars—it's on the fifth floor—but this alfresco lounge has something else to help set it above the crowd: a thoughtful cocktail list, substantial bar snacks (like mini samosas) and, most important, open seats. Moviegoers should stop by on Sundays and Mondays for sundown screenings of pop culture classics like Ferris Bueller's Day Off.

column7: An Old Style sign in front? That's a good omen. And half-pints to go? That's a boozer's paradise! Mix that in with a bartender who not only seems to know the regulars but also knows their drinks, and you've got a level of comfort and goodwill that makes for an excellent outing. A nod to the Irish name comes in the form of green walls and a neon shamrock—and that's it. Still, we'll take hospitality over exaggerated brogues any day.

column7: Laying claim to being Lincoln Park's oldest Irish pub isn't what made us fall for this bar. If you can, pop in on a slower night when the joint isn't overrun with Trixies.

column7: This warm, casual Edgewater hangout (formerly known as Sizzle on Broadway) is a great place to cozy up to a fireplace with a brewski and a plate of cheese fries during the winter months, but the beer garden also packs 'em in during the dog days. column7: Most people don't end up at this hard-to-get-to music venue unless they're seeing a live show, but the adjacent pub is actually worth a visit on its own. Sunday night's traditional Irish jam session lends support to the woody pub's Emerald Isle vibe; ditto for the respectable shepherd's pie. Cheapskates can seek out a spot on the patio and hear the indoor shows for free.

column7: If you've been searching for a hideout, this shadowy, windowless bar crammed between the Sheridan Red Line station and a liquor store is virtually invisible. Invisibility has its price.

column7: This new sporty-chic hot spot is hardly recognizable as the location that only recently housed Pops for Champagne. Even though the left side of the dual bar setup may be packed with loud, flat-screen–focused Colts and Hoosiers fans, the earth-tone stained-glass lighting and large windows in front give the surroundings a calm, open feel. If that's still too much to handle, the clientele on the less-rowdy right side is (just slightly) older, better dressed and wants to know more about you than just your sports loyalties.

column7: This bar is now closed.Upwardly mobile twenty- and thirtysomethings rejoice: Another upscale martini bar has arrived to service your libidos. The companion lounge to the attached Italian restaurant Extra Virgin has taken the theme one step further with a tiled mural of a full-breasted woman humping the ground. Otherwise, think library in the tropics furnished by Pottery Barn. The signature Mistress martini made with Effen cherry vodka is pretty Effen good, and a list of chic munchies is on hand for upscale noshing.

column7: There's very little about this classic tavern that's, well, little. Hordes of sports fans fill the cavernous indoor space to watch the game on several jumbo screens, drooling for the heaping burger-and-fries platters, generously cut steaks and big salads. And when the weather allows, tables are available outdoors and on the expansive, scenic rooftop, where bands occasionally perform.

column7: Banking on its building's supposed history as a former Capone speakeasy, this Loop joint draws its share of hungry tourists who—along with their beer, burger and fries—get a lunchtime eyeful of Chicago history via the photos and newspaper clippings plastered on the walls. Its downtown location situated beside the elevated tracks also makes this a great place for a little heel kicking and tie loosening after work.

column7: This spotless bar has been a Rogers Park fixture for ten years, and we're thinking it's due to the free barbecue doled out 5–8pm daily during the summer and the $1.25 drafts. Don't be surprised to see a blue-collar regular stroll in with 20 pounds of raw chicken and commence grilling—it's just a help-yourself kinda joint.

column7: Not to be confused with ESPN Zone, this cozy South Side spot banks on real sports fans and loyal locals rather than tourists and buffalo wings. column7: This bar sits high above Michigan Ave, just north of the fountain and atrium in the 12th-floor lobby of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. And as could be expected from a bar inside one of the city's most luxurious hotels, this place is old-school swanksville. Chairs upholstered in soft leather, ribbed corduroy and plush velvet surround ornate tables in a copper-tinted room that, after a couple martinis, you'll never want to leave.

column7: There's something endearing about a bar named for a 1908 New York version of Steve Bartman; Fred Merkle wrecked a victory for New York by failing to touch base in a playoff game against the Cubs. Not surprisingly, this watering hole bleeds true Cubby blue, complete with pennants and pics of old-time ballplayers. The taps lack heartier brews, focusing on the lighter lagers for drink-'em-down sports fans. The best deal is the $2 Honey Weisse "Leinies" on Thursdays.

column7: The glowing neon signs in the windows of this middlebrow supper club proclaim: steak, ribs and fish. That all of these demographics and more can comfortably mingle is a testament to the friendly staff, a surprisingly good jukebox and the shared belief that the first eight vodka tonics just weren't enough.

column7: With its come-as-you-are attitude and hefty selection of 20 eccentric burgers (Hawaiian, Truffle, Garbage, etc.), Duke's is built to last a lot longer than the building's previous tenants, who cycled through like Elizabeth Taylor's husbands. column7: At first glance, this square, low-lit bar seems a little too unkempt for the typical Southport crowd. But squint through the dimly lit room and you might find a group of girls leaning against the bar. They're leaning because they're drunk, and they're here because unlike some of the other bars on this strip, nobody's going to cut them off.

The result is a laid-back atmosphere that draws an eclectic mix of artists and nine-to-fivers.

column7: Pop into any bar boasting seven days of karaoke and you're likely to hear more than your fair share of Bon Jovi. column7: A college campus is hardly complete without a comfortable pub where the overworked and underpaid can reliably find their friends. column7: When you begin brunch by showing your ID at the door, you know you're in the right place for a Bloody Mary. Spicy and sweet, garnished with salami and completed with a beer back, it's practically a meal in itself. Don't let that distract you from the food, however. Breakfast tacos are a good way to spice up your egg intake. And the Spoke's signature "fatboy" burgers are thick, juicy and perfectly tender.

column7: If you're not familiar with the glorious convenience of "the slashy" (a.k.a. liquor store/bar), this old-man haunt is a good introduction. Sure, it looks like your average corner store: Cases of beer, liquor and cheap wine surround retail shelves stocked with junk food in a fluorescent-lit room. But wander toward the dimly lit back of the store and you'll find yourself in bar country wondering whether or not you should have a couple before heading home with a fresh six-pack.

column7: This bar is now closed.This place is so white. Literally. The upholstery, the curtains, the floor, the ceiling—all of it stark white. Thankfully, the college-age clientele is sufficiently diverse and good-looking (if you're into nighttime Ray-Ban wearers and Tyra Banks look-alikes), and the Euro-trash house music is so pounding that you won't mind the blinding decor. If the whiteness disorients, just remember to make like the ironic mullet you'll spot here on occasion—stay close to the front bar if you want to chat, and party down in the back.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

column7: Part garden patio, part sidewalk cafe, the outdoor space at this stalwart is a visual reminder of Wicker Park's shifting population. El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 50, 56, 72.. Sun–Fri 11am–2am; Sat 11am–3am. Average beer: $4.

column7: Pity the Printers Row outpost of this local pub. In the suburbs it gets so much more respect—people are constantly drooling over the famous "Hackneyburger." Its lone city outpost isn't given as much acclaim, but it's nonetheless a warm, inviting, friendly place to get a drink. And they seem to be grooming other Chicago legends: The drinks menu features local beers, vodkas and gins.

column7: This recently opened sister club to late-night party parlor RiNo combines luxury amenities (private lockers and basement lounge for VIPs, extraattentive staff for everyone) and lots of wood, stone and lacquer in the storied former Pasha space. The clear but rich Funktion One sound system might be the biggest draw of all, and owners Michael Bisbee and Michael Kaulentis promise to keep the DJ roster flush with bicoastal talent to make use of it. Currently, there's no cover and with influential promoters like Tony Macey throwing parties here, it's sure to be sizzling on summer nights.

column7: As in a middle-school art classroom, you'll find row upon row of paintings on butcher paper covering the bar's bronze-plated, mosaic-tile walls. Whether it's Surrealist, Abstract, Cubist or Impressionist, the more you drink, the better it will look.

column7: There goes the neighborhood. Once sleepy and under-appreciated, this raucous spot has single-handedly turned up the volume in West Town. It's packed with tanned, gelled and button-downed dudes devil-horning to old Metallica and gawking at chicks in shirts that look like they've been mauled by tigers. So far, the locals haven't called the cops with noise complaints, but the fashion police should be on their way any minute.

column7: Stumble into this Edgewater dive most nights and the drinkers bellied up to the bar look as if they've been sucking suds since the place opened at 7am. This is your typical shot-and-beer bar, but if simply chugging bores you, there's a pool table, some TVs and a jukebox featuring choices from Hank Williams to the Clash. Oh, and now that a regular sold the bar owner a piano he garbage-picked from a nearby church, you also can tickle the ivories.

column7: The Holiday opened its doors on Madison and Green in 1979, but moved to its current digs when gentrification got a strong foothold. The self-proclaimed "Best steak and eggs in town" is no idle boast here, and plenty of blue-collar types congregate at the crack of dawn for that particular delight (and perhaps a few Budweiser longnecks) to start their day. A few drinks after breakfast gets us in the mood to pour money into the well-stocked CD jukebox.

Skip all that, or at least cut it down to a low roar, by grabbing one of the few tables on the sidewalk patio. The people-watching is well worth the tab for pricey cocktails. 1007 N Rush St between Oak St and Bellevue Pl (312-664-1001). El: Red to Clark/Division. Bus: 22 (24hrs), 36, 70. Sun–Fri 5pm–2am; Sat 5pm–3am. Average cocktail: $7.

column7: The late-night hanging at this River North spot (RiNo, get it?) feels like a wealthy socialite's loft party for pretty people with fairly pedestrian taste in music. The casually trendy ladies seem to love dancing on the furniture—which makes sense when you consider they're usually already drunk when they arrive at 1:30am.

column7: Because drinking on an empty stomach is a one-way ticket to drunk-dialing your ex, falling asleep in the bathroom or other drama, this wine bar thankfully puts just as much focus on the food. The housemade empanada hides earthy mushrooms inside its flaky crust; hefty crab cakes get a golden exterior of panko crumbs; a caprese salad gets a twist by using blue cheese instead of mozz; and a pizza topped with caramelized onions and pears goes perfectly with an off-dry riesling.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 36, 62, 65

column7: When you first walk in, you might get what feels like the stink-eye from the regulars of this Humboldt Park hangout. Don't fret; they're just not used to outsiders. Have a Corona and they'll beg you to stay for the samba sounds of Ensconacion Tropical. Ask anyone at the bar; it's the best band around. Just don't plan on a regular music schedule or even fixed hours of operation—this place opens and closes whenever the owner "feels like it."

column7: It's easy to lose track of time in this unpretentious, friendly pub—the regulars actually seem to enjoy one another's company, the tap offerings are adequate, and the signature Black and Sam's (Guinness and Sam Adams Boston Lager) are gulpable. column7: This rustic, knotty-pine joint has such a high degree of patriotism on display that it not only has two large American flags up, but a boycott France sign, too. It's pretty much a shot-and-beer venue, with domestic bottles for $2.50, imports for $3. Specialty drinks are not a specialty, but the bartender aims to please, so don't be shy about asking. There's an interesting old-fashioned phone booth with a light that goes on when you open the door, but better bring your cell; the phone itself is out of service.

column7: This Far North Side chapter of the Mullen's fraternity is for those who want their bench-pressed, score-obsessed sports bar, but don't want to jockey for a seat in the jockstrap that is Wrigleyville. column7: Stretching the northerly boundaries of Cubbie territory nearly to Irving Park Road, this dive-among-dives has only one thing characteristically Wrigleyville about it: its name. The first sign: the bartender's missing her four front teeth. The second sign: The low, garage band–ready stage with cowboy hats atop the amplifiers. The final clue: the refreshing absence of loud, red-faced bros and their stumbling Botox broads.

column7: Order up a buck's worth of nuts from the stylized "nut hut" behind the bar, but be warned that some assertive squirrels might be hanging around the back door looking for offerings. While you're being entertained at what's surely the only bar in town where you might come across live squirrels, take down $3 domestics and chat with the bartender about that glass-enclosed 1873 Winchester rifle behind the bar or those two dozen hanging ceramic steins. If you luck out, the owner might be serving her Texas-style chili or juicy chicken.

column7: In the late-night/early-morning hours, Lawrence Street can often resemble an urban ghost town. DJs (Wed–Sat) and karaoke (Sun) are a plus, but the late-night liquor license keeps us stumbling back, again and again.

That Guinness getcha hungry? Dig into menu highlights like shepherd's pie.

Beer aside, another draw is the lively and friendly crowd bellying up to quaff a few while the Sox or Cubs battle it out on five TVs.

column7: Under framed pictures of smiling customers, a sweet old bartender pours you cheap PBR ($5 pitchers, $1.50 glasses) and asks how you've been. It's easy to relax at this homey spot (the retro bowling game was the clincher for us), which feels as comforting as your grandparents' basement—with the added perk of booze.

column7: Though not as sprawling as its flagship brewpub on Clybourn Avenue, Goose Island's baby brother won't disappoint fans of the original. Located within earshot of Wrigley's roar, the digs are sports-themed and the folk even sportier. But that doesn't mean the bartenders here aren't beer geeks. They're obsessed with what's flowing from their goose-headed taps and more than happy to recommend a perfect brew-burger pairing.

column7: This bilevel, spa-theme lounge is decorated with carefully lit cherry blossoms and a steady sheet of water cascading down the walls. According to the owners, it's the most luxurious, upscale spot in town. So why is every guy dressed like he's at a Cubs game? And why are all the ladies dressed like Fly Girls? We like the hip-hop they play, too (particularly on Tuesday nights, when they get the best crowd in town). But come on, people: You already finagled your way past the doorman—you can at least look like you belong.

column7: What used to be the Berghoff bar is now essentially a cleaner version of its former self (with a frilly martini list to boot). The room is a little airier since the wall between restaurant and bar has been taken down, but the century-old German pub was always about that gorgeous, room-length bar. And the mix of tourists, after-work suits and afternoon men won't notice the renovations when they're bellying up to that wooden monolith.

column7: With its friendly staff and polished beer garden, it's a shame that such a nice bar is experiencing an identity crisis. No matter what, this place doesn't want to be called a gay bar. column7: This woody bar has the same investment banker–look-alike clientele and beer selection as every other Irish-tinged sports bar on this strip of Southport, but a few curiosities remain. The sepia-toned photos of the bar's namesake, circa early 20th century, posing victorious in a wide variety of sports (conquering a steep mountainside on skis; winning an auto race) is puzzlingly humorous, while the large aquarium behind the bar—full of water and coral, yet entirely fish-free—is just plain puzzling.

column7: Bar owner Michael Jettner has done everything right at this Gladstone Park pub. He stocks a dozen beers on tap (Blue Moon, Woodchuck Cider, etc.), nearly twice that number by the bottle, and keeps on hand all the requisite extras like darts, digital jukebox and a half-dozen TVs. Thankfully, none of it distracts from the floor-to-ceiling brick and exposed beams (not that the malecentric crowd really cares).

column7: Take the aesthetic of Rain Forest Cafe, throw in some "jungle beats" and hire a crew of skinny, modern-day hippies to run the place, and you might have something resembling this sister bar to Funky Buddha Lounge. Concerned with your overall wellness as much as your level of inebriation, the alcohol here is all organic. column149: Healy's Westside It's rare to see the cavernous main room of this bar packed to capacity. It really only happens on St. Patrick's Day, according to our tattooed bartender with the pompadour. The rest of the year is spent counting down the days till the drunkenest of holidays while drinking Jäger and Newcastle (which are on tap), playing darts in back, and filling up on Guinness beef stew and fish and chips. 7321 W Madison Ave, Forest Park (708-366-4277). . Mon–Thu 3pm–2am; Fri, Sat 11:30am–3am; Sun 11:30am–2am. Average beer: $4.
column187: Food served

column7: Perhaps the dingiest option on the Madison Street strip, this bar is lit and decorated like a cave and smells a bit like a toilet. But that doesn't faze the college kids who come for the fraternal atmosphere, pool table and, of course, the cheap booze.
column149: Murphy's Pub Perhaps the dingiest option on the Madison Street strip, this bar is lit and decorated like a cave and smells a bit like a toilet. But that doesn't faze the college kids who come for the fraternal atmosphere, pool table and, of course, the cheap booze. 7414 N Madison St Forest Park (708-366-3008). . Mon–Thu 11am–2am; Fri–Sat 11am–3am; Sun 11am–2am . Average beer: $3.

column7: With 25 plasma screens strategically arranged throughout these two wood-rich rooms, there's absolutely no place to escape the game. That's good if you're a Notre Dame fan; if you're not, you'd better go on a night when the Irish aren't fighting. Or just go when the games are over—it's a better time to turn your game on anyway.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 74, 76

column7: The museum of antiquated taverns needs to add this place to its collection. It has wall-to-wall original wood paneling, a pool table with matted and faded felt, and a vague race-car theme that seems like it was lovingly put together some 30 years ago. The patrons here look like they showed up in their youth and never left, but they all seem to like the friendly bar matron who smokes Newports in the most desultory fashion.

column7: The owners behind this tiny corner tavern must've taken a class called "Friendly Neighborhood Bar 101" because they've nailed down all the requisite perks. There's a brand-spankin'-new digital jukebox on the exposed brick wall, several TVs, cheap pub fare, daily drink specials, ladies' night (Tuesday), karaoke night (Saturday), dart competitions and free pool on Sundays.

column7: Sinking the eight ball without scratching and the siren song of a second biscotto are perhaps the only real pressures at this Edgewater café. Because the only shots this place serves up are espresso (although beer is on offer), it has a neighborhood rec-center vibe. But when you consider the improv comedy on Fridays and free Wi-Fi, you won't miss the booze.

column7: Tucked away in the shadow of the Western Avenue bridge, this cozy, candlelit bar seems (at least early in the night) like a good place to write your long-awaited debut novel while nursing one of 40 eclectic, hard-to-find beers. Just don't get too comfy, Hemingway: The rowdy, late-night rush is this establishment's bread and butter. So stay and spot the subject of your next broken-heart tale.

column7: This ideal neighborhood dive is somehow still an overlooked gem. The wood paneling is balanced out by exposed brick, a fantastic tin ceiling and stained-glass lamps hanging over the bar. The giant outdoor patio is one of this area's best-kept secrets—toss horseshoes, play the bean-bag game, or just drink and smoke. And don't mind the new condo-dwellers across the street complaining about the noise; they'll either move soon or come down to join you.

column7: It looks like the owners have sunk a fair amount of dough into this spiffy Irish pub and saloon. A digital juke hangs on the wall, flat-screen TVs abound and the comfy seating in back makes the place feel lounge-y. Though there are plenty of gimmicks (Wednesday, for example, is "Get hammered and nailed" night, which includes a cocktail and manicure for $12), most people are happiest just chilling out with a beer.

column7: Among the city's collection of gay leather bars, this dimly lit establishment—free of the usual blinding lights and techno beats—is perhaps the most laid-back and conversation-friendly of them all. Muted porn videos play on four out of seven TVs, while an older crowd drinks cheap beers (50-cent drafts on Sundays). Don't fret if you happen to waltz in on a day when your leathers are at the cleaners: Jeans and a T-shirt are just as common here as chaps and a vest.

column7: We've bellied up to many Irish pubs, but we've never seen anything quite as striking as this sporty, well-worn pub's wall filled with Irish coats of arms. Tacked up against a green backdrop, those decorations bring an Old-World–Ireland feel to the place, so it's all the more puzzling that there's zero Guinness on tap and not one Irish lad in sight.

column7: Drinking here is like getting into the DeLorean and traveling back to 1955—sort of like when you're just drunk enough at Green Mill to think it's the '40s. Eclectic, mismatched furniture and an old blues-heavy jukebox set the mood for kicking back or rackin' 'em up at the two vintage pool tables. Just be careful, McFly: The bartenders will not hesitate to embarrass you on the felt.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9 Ashland, 80 Irving Park

column7: This hipster cocktail lounge is exactly what you'd expect from a bar named after a line of T.S. Eliot poetry: pristine (the carefully constructed cocktails are excellent), pretentious (you won't find a sign on the door—just look for the long lines) and, ultimately, completely and inarguably gorgeous. Check out the new fall cocktail menu, where an Autumn Sazerac is made with apple-flavored schnapps and a Sasparilla Sling gets root-beer bitters.
column149: The Violet Hour This hipster cocktail lounge is exactly what you'd expect from a bar named after a line of T.S. column7: Most great dives look as though they haven't seen so much as a pledge-soaked rag since the end of World War II. With that in mind, this little, bottles-only (despite its name) tavern is oddly modern. Its scant decor—beer promo posters of bikini-clad women with 'dos straight out of a hair-metal video and an aging jukebox with tunes to match—appears to have been updated as recently as the end of the Cold War.
column144: El: Brown to Western. Bus: 11, 49 (24hrs), X49, 78

column7: If drinking at a bowling alley seems a little too Roseanne for a posh crew like yours, you obviously haven't been to lanes like these before. The rambunctious singles crowd seems more interested in each other (and the neon-bright martinis and enormous screens playing larger-than-life music videos) than they do actually picking up a bowling ball. One way or another, you'll probably score.

column7: This worn-around-the-edges watering hole is the last place you'd expect to find old men gathered around a horseshoe bar, glued to reruns of Will & Grace. Then again, weird sightings are de rigueur here: Dearly departed Sally herself allegedly shows up (in ghost form) near the jukebox every now and again. But when a bar is this minimal—the only eye candy here is an attractive female bartender standing against a background of Christmas lights and wood paneling—patrons are happy for something new to look at.

column7: Kind of a cross between Cheers and the bar in "The Iceman Cometh," where the "foolosopher" in residence is 75-year-old regular Mikey Voss ("The one thing I know is I know nothing"), this shot-and-beer joint seems much-loved by the regulars. Perhaps it's the diplomacy on display. The northernmost TV has Cubs games on, while the southernmost TV airs Sox games. Is everybody happy? A few more cheap beers, and any tune you want on the online jukebox, and you will be.

column7: Although this bar in the former Pepper Lounge space doesn't stray too far from the Wrigleyville mold, its dark woods, exposed brick and sports-memorabilia deficiency seem classier than many of the surrounding drunk dens. The bar's namesake half-yard glass can be filled with more than a dozen draft brews and trotted out to the rear beer garden, which sports three old horse stables the owners say will eventually become semiprivate nooks for small groups.
column60: Mon–Fri 5pm–2am; Sat noon–3am; Sun noon–2am (opens at 11am on Cubs game days)

column7: Owner Dave Miller is a classically trained musician who has transformed this neighborhood tavern into a cozy, low-key venue for those of his kind. With the Art Deco–accented barroom, expanded beer selection and nightly performances of jazz, bluegrass, rock and even opera, music makers and music admirers can grab a pint and oscillate between fortissimo and pianissimo all night long.

column7: For most of you, this place isn't worth the hike. But for you Far North Siders out there, it's an oasis in your own back yard. This 60-year-old gem offers three-dozen beers (including La Fin du Monde, Delirium Tremens and Smithwicks), cracker-thin "Chicago bar–style" pizza and herb-flecked garlic fries that have quite the loyal local following. Our only hope is that someone fixes the schizo jukebox that's been playing Hall & Oates every other song.

column7: Admittedly, we were a little sad when we heard that Lincoln Park stalwart Lawry's Tavern was being replaced by yet another Irish pub. Our period of mourning, however, was short. Sure, Lawry's had character (i.e., shitty beer, laugh-riot regulars and wood-paneled walls), but come on, this place has Lindemans' framboise, Three Floyd's Alpha King and Deirium Tremens on tap; a digital juke box; and a full menu of burgers and fish-and-chips. We still miss Lawry's pool table, though.
