column7: Feel the need to pregame before a concert at the Congress? There's no closer place than this largely Latino dive. Some of the regulars are about as welcoming as the caged windows out front, but if you give 'em your best Una Negra Modelo, por favor and put a few Mexican polka tunes on the juke, you'll be shooting pool like a local in no time.
column144: El: Blue to Western. Bus: 49 (24hrs), X49, 56, 73

column7: Well, "winners" might be a stretch, but we're certainly not going to call the folks who sit at the green Formica counter in this windowless Holiday Inn lobby bar losers. Besides, we're right there with them, watching the television in silence and slowly sipping our beers with satisfaction, knowing that no matter what, nobody's going to find (much less bother) us here.

column7: This self-proclaimed bikini bar could best be described as a poor man's Hooters, but instead of having an owl as a mascot, it's chosen (egads!) a crab. Surprisingly, it isn't as tawdry as you'd expect, although it could stand to lose the plethora of beer-company swag hanging from every inch of the place. If you don't have the balls to go to a real strip club but still want to ogle some ladies, you could do worse. And with the thin crowd most nights, you're highly unlikely to be spotted by anyone you know.

column7: Any of this spot's divey iniquities can be forgiven with the $1 mugs of Old Style. Rose—the cute, old Eastern European owner-bartender—hasn't changed a thing since the '70s: A shingled awning hangs over the back of the bar, wood paneling lines the walls and plenty of eclectic grandma knickknacks mingle with the bottles of liquor. And at seven plays for a buck, not even the jukebox prices have changed.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74, 76

column7: The windowless front door isn't exactly a welcome mat, but once inside Christina's compact, cozy digs (and after an insanely cheap $2 Guinness) you'll feel right at home. The football pennants hanging over the bar and baseball on several TVs scream sports bar, but the Talking Heads and '60s-era Stones on the juke combined with the bartender's Iggy and the Stooges shirt say otherwise.

column7: A friendly late-night joint is hard to find. One where off-duty cops, dolled-up hipsters and sporty types drink together in harmony, like this one, is even harder. Inside, the exposed brick wall and candlelit bar makes for a cozy atmosphere. Add some fine picks by the DJ and two of the nicest bartenders around, and you'll definitely be back for seconds.

column7: Merry ol' England this ain't, but it's tough to find a sports hub this inviting along Broadway. In the front, kegs are stacked next to a pinball machine; near the back, a disco ball is suspended over the jukebox; and Cubs signs are peppered throughout the narrow space. Yeah, there are some odd decorating choices, but any place where the off-duty bartender buys us a shot gets our vote.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington; Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77

column7: A tasty pie in a laid-back atmosphere is the specialty of this cash-only Andersonville joint. We recommend the house pizza, a unique combo of eggplant, jalapeño peppers and garlic on a crispy (but thankfully not cracker-thin) crust. And if you're just in it for the booze, grab a Delirium Tremens and a seat at one of the couches in the back that surround a big-screen TV. But don't try bringing back munchies; like at home, there's a no-eating rule in the living room.

column7: Nick Novich (the proprietor of Nick's Uptown and the original Nick's in Wicker Park) must view his newest bar as a long-term investment, but we see it as yet another sign of the inevitable Uptown renaissance. The bartenders admit the place hasn't yet caught on (weary Truman professors being the exception), but with its exposed brick walls, bright red bar, and chic, lofty atmosphere, it's only a matter of time before it's packed.

column7: When we strolled into this endearingly tacky Latino holdout tucked into a gentrifying residential block, a tipsy twentysomething swiveled his stool our way, raised his hands to the sky and gleefully announced to the four other people in the place, "Finally! You're here." It was drunk talk all right, but this stranger summed up exactly how this bewitching bar makes you feel: like it's been waiting all these years for you to become a regular.

column7: This freak-friendly dance destination in Lakeview built its reputation back in the mid-'80s with a mix of German new wave music, art installations and even transvestite shows. column7: Literally overshadowed by its neighbor, the popular restaurant Hacienda Tecalitlan, it's easy to miss this bare-bones Mexican hangout. An open bar stool is tough to come by, but thankfully there are a few tables scattered throughout and pool and foosball to keep you busy. If you're not up for bar sports, here's a game: Count whether there are more posters displaying Mexican pride or women in bikinis.

column7: This intimate basement club in the River North gallery district underwent a lot of changes in 2006: The glammy crowd moved on to new places and the big-name house, techno and electro DJs came back. Not to mention, the sound system has gotten beefed up to please audiophiles. On weekends, it's anew destination for serious danceheads and budding DJs, while weeknights are ripe for experimentation.

column7: Designed in cool grays and browns by local master of stylish interiors, Suhail, as a kind of futuristic listeners' lounge, this West Town club has lively and often risky bookings, which have made it a favorite of neighborhood hipsters. The audiophile jet set loves the spectacularly clear sound system, and it's hard not to fall for the reasonable price of beer and often high-end wines. Monthly Dark Wave Disco night (usually the third Thursday) and visits from touring DJs such as Philly faves Diplo and Rich Medina are packed solid with lubricated, in-the-know dancers. On Sunday nights, there's a reliably thumping reggae/dub event curated by former Deadly Dragon Soundsystem instigator, RikShaw.
column144: El: Blue to Chicago. Bus: 9, X9, 66

column7: Originally on the fourth floor of the magnificent Wrigleyville building (also home to Metro; see Music venues, Rock, pop & hip-hop), this venerated dance club is now in the basement. A makeover in 2006 slicked up the looks a notch and brought back a vibrant young crowd. But more important, the club boasts a world-class Funktion One sound system, which sounds tremendous on the central dance floor. Cutting-edge DJs from Europe, Detroit and Chicago form the bulk of the weekend bookingswith house, techno and electro styles; but local mash-up and indie jocks rule on bargain weekday nights.

column7: When this place was The Note, the focus was on the bands on stage. Now, of course, those bands are gone, and the focus is onnothing. And that's exactly what this rapidly yuppifying neighborhood needs.

column7: Despite new ownership, the underground lounge formerly known as krem retains its white-on-white interior and continues to play host to a crowd of highly coiffed twentysomethings throwing back bottle service. True to the bar's new moniker, though, the bartenders in candy-colored wigs serving candy-colored cocktails— and the sea of white smiles and shiny outfits illuminated by a saturating black light—add up to something pretty dreamlike. Or nightmarish, depending on your taste.

column7: After a recent makeover, this pub is quite sleek. Two new pool tables sport virgin felt and cues that actually have tips. For Madison Street, that's uncharacteristically classy.

column7: Because it's on the outer edge of Madison Street, beyond the throng of deafening bro bars, this warm, inviting place has a little more freedom to be classy. Sure, it's still an Irish pub, but that has less to do with shamrocks than Smithwick's and fish and chips. Flickering candles line the dark-wood bar, which sports a full wine rack and a respectable selection of bottled microbrews. There's also a conversation-friendly outdoor patio with six umbrella-topped tables.

column7: Posters of Jaws, American Graffiti, The Three Stooges and other pop-culture classics line every inch of the exposed-brick walls, adding to the familiar and homey feel of the place. We only have one warning: If loud jazz, blues and rock bands aren't your thing, call ahead to see if one's slotted to play that night. A live band playing in such a tight, narrow space isn't exactly friendly on the ears. But if eardrum-bursting sound is your thing, rock on, my friend.

If the bar area gets to crowded, though, make sure you check out elegant back patio, which is open all year. It's one of our faves.

column149: Circle Lanes This bar opened in the 1940s, and it seems like time has stood still since the '70s. The bar that adjoins the bowling alley area looks and feels like a wood-paneled rec room, with a pool table, jukebox, and lots of bowling and pool league plaques on the walls. If you don't bowl, you could be just as happy throwing back a few while playing some country or Elvis tunes. 7244 Circle Ave, Forest Park (708-366-2810). El: Blue to Forest Park. Tue–Fri noon to midnight; Sat, Sun noon–10pm. Average beer: $2.50.
column187: Pool table

column7: Contrary to its name, there's little that's unexpected about this smallish yet pleasant sports bar. Fittingly nestled near Wrigley Field, its flat screens are dedicated year-round to ball games. A half-dozen beers are on tap (no out-of-the-ordinary brews, though) and the menu of pub grub is just greasy enough to satisfy the slew of regulars eating burgers and drinking pitchers.
column149: Dark Horse Tap and Grille Contrary to its name, there's little that's unexpected about this smallish yet pleasant sports bar. Fittingly nestled near Wrigley Field, its flat screens are dedicated year-round to ball games. A half-dozen beers are on tap (no out-of-the-ordinary brews, though) and the menu of pub grub is just greasy enough to satisfy the slew of regulars eating burgers and drinking pitchers. 3443 N Sheffield Ave between Newport and Cornelia Aves (773-248-4400). El: Red to Addison. Bus: 8, 22, 152. Mon–Fri 4:30pm–2am; Sat 11am–3am; Sun 11am–2am. Average beer: $3.50.

column7: This new Logan Square bar has everything you could ask for—that is, as long as you don't ask for too much. The spare, dim room has plenty of hipster atmosphere (but no hipster snobbery); ample seating at a wood paneled bar; and a delicious beer on tap that you can't get anywhere else (just point to the unmarked draft handle adorned with antlers and tell the bartender you'll have some of that).
column144: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 82
column149: The Burlington This new Logan Square bar has everything you could ask for—that is, as long as you don't ask for too much. column7: When we entered this worn-out old corner tap, the four blue-collar folks at the bar turned from their $2 beers and stared. "The gang's all here, so who the hell could this be?" they must've thought. So how do you enter this finicky fold? Order a cheap brew, throw a block of Journey on the juke and challenge the bar's stick-slinger to a game of pool. And after you strategically lose, buy that man another beer.
column144: El: Brown to Rockwell. Bus: 49, X49, 81
column149: Loafers When we entered this worn-out old corner tap, the four blue-collar folks at the bar turned from their $2 beers and stared. column7: Strolling into this posh, cavernous River North nightspot, we can see how it might induce what its name promises. The allure is the peak-of-opulence decor—a stunning mix of modern touches, plantlife and antique architectural finds. Towering over plush booths and a large dance floor are backlit photos of soaked and scantily clad models. It's a touch outdone only by two ginormous griffin lights that flank the first of three bars.
column149: Climax Lounge Strolling into this posh, cavernous River North nightspot, we can see how it might induce what its name promises. The allure is the peak-of-opulence decor—a stunning mix of modern touches, plantlife and antique architectural finds. Towering over plush booths and a large dance floor are backlit photos of soaked and scantily clad models. It's a touch outdone only by two ginormous griffin lights that flank the first of three bars. 324 W Chicago Ave between Franklin and Orleans Sts (312-280-9800). El: Brown to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156. Wed–Fri 9pm–2am; Sat 9am–3am (closed Sun–Tue). Average cocktail: $10.

column7: It's not much to look at on the outside, but inside this Northwest Side bar, you'll find a black lacquered horseshoe bar, comfy stools and a half-dozen Mexican beers served ice cold with a bowl of lime slices and a shaker of salt. Come on Salsa Mondays for a free lesson, $1 tacos and $2 MGDs and Lites. Be sure to try a ceviche (Mexican sushi) special—delish shrimp, avocado and cilantro in lime juice on a tostada for only two bucks.

column7: Just so you know, this place is named after the Texas-Mexico river, not the John Wayne movie. Regardless, we're not quibbling, we're just here for the Cazadores tequila on the advice of the friendly bartender, Mike (and since he's been the head 'keep for 27 years, we figure he must know a good drink). As with any good dive worth its semidumpy kitsch, there are breast mugs behind the bar, while a worn rug painting of dogs playing pool presides over the billiards table.
column149: Rio Bravo Just so you know, this place is named after the Texas-Mexico river, not the John Wayne movie. column7: There's nothing out of the ordinary at this new Loop bar and grill, and that suits the famished financial district clientele just fine. They're just happy to have a decent option for an off-the-clock cocktail or a quick lunch that's above bottom-feeder pub grub. The varied menu offers coconut shrimp, several salads, sweet potato fries and a meatloaf sandwich, which can be washed down with one of 18 bottled beers.

column7: From the music on the speakers (Nat King Cole et al.) to the rat-pack decor and carefully shaken martinis, this Logan Square corner bar is surprising all the twentysomething post-hipsters flocking to it. It's not just that the bar is a far cry from the dive that preceded it—really, it's a far cry from anything that's been built since 1940. Recent additions to the menu like fish tacos and Cuban sandwiches make it easy to spend summer nights lingering on the walled-in patio.
column60: Mon–Thu 4pm–2am; Fri, Sun noon–2am; Sat noon–3am

column7: "Who's gay? Who's straight? Who cares?" is the attitude at this new Boystown Irish-themed pub. After all, you're just as likely to see a bunch of frumpy yuppies in Cubs caps washing down burgers with pints of Guinness as you are to spy a gaggle of pretty boys uniting for a drunken chorus of "Save a Horse, Ride a Cowboy."

column7: This bar is now closed.Nostalgia-starved twentysomethings pack this dual-level Lincoln Park bar as much to devour the VH1 I Love the '80s decor as to order winkingly from its decidedly childish menu. Leather booths upstairs add a touch of maturity, but the real action is downstairs, where vinyl album covers from Duran Duran and the Romantics open up wistful floodgates to usher in eats like SpaghettiOs, Tater Tots, and cookies and milk.

column7: Somehow this bar manages to marry the Hofbrau beer and bench-style seating of a traditional German beer hall with the flat-screens and University of Wisconsin pennants of a familiar college sports bar. So expect to hear as many shouts of "touchdown" as the bar's namesake incantation.

column7: Just as Clarke's on Belmont spawned After Dark, its sibling on Lincoln Avenue recently begot this neighboring nightspot. It shares a kitchen with the 24-hour diner but offers its own menu of barcentric eats. Black-and-white photos of ballplayers dot the walls, but the dimly lit digs; deep, cushy booths; and mammoth glazed-wood bar make things feel cozier than at most sporty spots in this 'hood.

column7: In case you missed all the concert posters, the flat screens showing performance footage or the corner stage (which, more often than not, has a band on it), live music is the theme of this new South Side pub. But with such a good beer selection and a friendly staff, you don't need to be into the music to want to spend your night here.

column7: With eight TVs (inevitably tuned to Bears, Cubs, and the Fighting Illini) and a plethora of drafts (Fat Tire, Stella, Woodchuck cider) it's clear you're waist-deep in jock country here. Test your sports knowledge in the Tuesday night trivia contest, when pints are priced at $3.75, or throw a sports-themed party in the back room with ten (count 'em) TVs. The feel-good, hangover-friendly food—crispy Reuben rolls, deep-fried mac-and-cheese bites—is served when you need it most: Saturdays and Sundays from 11am to 2pm.

column7: Curiously, there's not one piano in this place. For crissakes, we didn't even hear any Billy Joel piping from the digital juke. So what's the deal with Piano Man? A short jaunt from the Friendly Confines, this corner tap's a bare-bones Cubs bar with a bounty of TVs, delightful floor-to-ceiling windows that open up on nice days and one really misleading moniker.

column7: (This place is closed.)The shuttering of Lakeview's Twisted Spoke left its regulars—the type who'll listen to the Baseball Furies but aren't interested in baseball—adrift in a sea of Cubs bars. But after vamping up the place with stained-glass windows and a marble bar top, Brody's has opened. And people are drifting back, lured by a better beer selection, barbecue-slanted menu items like pulled pork, and the promise of a live-music stage in the coming months.

column7: If Caesar likes you, feel free to enter. The vigilant dog at the door of this sports bar has freaked out a few would-be customers, but we're brave, and Caesar turned out to be cool. He's just protecting the place's character—which is helped by exposed brick and old wood, and hindered by buffalo wings and a big screen. The beer selection goes beyond the basics, with three dozen bottles and ten drafts; if the unseasonable warmth keeps up, sample your way through the list in the beer garden.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 11, 76

column7: Opened by the team behind Wrigleyville's Trace, this enormous new drinkery brings a taste of the prototypical Lincoln Park sports bar to Division Street. column7: Legend has it that the Velvet Underground once rocked the stage at Mother's, which opened its doors in 1968. But don't come here looking for avant-garde rock. These days, Mother's is all about pleasing the sweat-drenched, booze-soaked Division Street masses who pack the dance floor into the early morning hours hoping to grind against Mr. or Ms. Right—or at least Mr. or Ms. Tonight.

But a sports bar this isn't; on Wednesdays the sound of blues music prevails and Thursdays techno and house heads take over the back room to dance to a DJ until last call.

column7: English is definitely a second language at this lively Polish bar, and while it's not much to look at on the outside, the inside is like stepping into an Eastern Euro vacation. Okocim drafts are nicely chilled, Zywiec is on offer for a great session beer, Polish music abounds and even the TVs are tuned to Polish cable. The shiny black lacquered bar and the red, green and yellow lights are throwbacks to the disco era, setting the mood for fruity concoctions like the raspberrytini.

column7: Microbrews, musicians and a kick-ass sound system combine to make you feel like you're in a cool, hippie, music nerd's college apartment, minus the patchouli. With portraits of rock & roll heroes lining the walls (along with a shot of De Niro from his cutting-edge Johnny Boy days), comfy sofas for lounging and a collection of bootlegged live concerts on CDR, this place pulls off what every Hard Rock Café aims to do. All 16 beers on tap, including micros like Rogue Dead Guy ale, run through clean, well-maintained lines and come out frosty.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74, 76

column7: Behind its blacked-out windows, this dark, well-worn dive is an unlikely spot for live music. Jazz groups hold court every Thursday, and on Sunday nights, El Gato earns its billing as "the hottest spot for T-girls in Chicago," when Latin grooves and an X-rated transgender burlesque show take over.

column149: El Gato Negro Behind its blacked-out windows, this dark, well-worn dive is an unlikely spot for live music. Jazz groups hold court every Thursday, and on Sunday nights, El Gato earns its billing as "the hottest spot for T-girls in Chicago," when Latin grooves and an X-rated transgender burlesque show take over. 1461 W Irving Park Rd between Ashland and Southport Aves (773-472-9353). El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, X9, 22, 80, X80. Sun–Fri noon–2am; Sat noon–3am. Average beer: $5.
column187: Live bandsGay

column7: A Venus de Milo decanter filled with booze and porcelain fiddles brimming with bourbon may not be your idea of high art, but they're someone's: Said objets d'arts sit next to an old-timey cigarette machine, which might be to blame for at least some of the burn marks on the wooden bar. Hard-luck tales are spun from grizzled patrons hunching over $2 drafts amid neon signs and come-hither chicks on beer posters.
column149: Ted's Northwest Liquors A Venus de Milo decanter filled with booze and porcelain fiddles brimming with bourbon may not be your idea of high art, but they're someone's: Said objets d'arts sit next to an old-timey cigarette machine, which might be to blame for at least some of the burn marks on the wooden bar. Hard-luck tales are spun from grizzled patrons hunching over $2 drafts amid neon signs and come-hither chicks on beer posters. 5223 W Addison St between Laramie and Lockwood Aves (773-777-5175). Bus: 54, X54, 85, 152. Sun–Fri 9am–2am; Sat 9am–3am. Average beer: $2.

column7: When the Inn of Chicago revealed its newly renovated space earlier this year, we did a double take: The interior seemed far too slick and sexy for a place called an Inn. Its lounge is much the same: With its cool silver tones, backlit bar and colorful martinis, it's thankfully not so much "lobby" as it is "clubby."
column149: Inn Bar When the Inn of Chicago revealed its newly renovated space earlier this year, we did a double take: The interior seemed far too slick and sexy for a place called an Inn. Its lounge is much the same: With its cool silver tones, backlit bar and colorful martinis, it's thankfully not so much "lobby" as it is "clubby." 162 E Ohio St between Michigan Ave and St. Clair St (312-787-3100). column187: Conversation friendly

column7: Longtime regulars of La Pasadita said goodbye to their beloved watering hole as different owners turned the largely Spanish-speaking spot into this sports bar. There's a new sign, sure, but to call the place "new" is a bit of an exaggeration: The interior isn't drastically different, and the addition of a few flat-screen TVs only puts its already obvious signs of aging—scuffed hardwood, yellowing walls, beat-up tables—further into relief.
column144: El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 9, X9, 50, 56, 72

column7: Ignore the stench of stale cigarettes if you can. And don't worry about those old codgers in the corner; they're drunk anyway. Just focus on what a time capsule this is—'80s-era Bud Light posters above the weathered, brown leather booths; the vintage (working) refrigerator—and how cheap the beer is ($2 for Miller Light).

column7: Drunken dining is made überconvenient at this dank, sardine can–size bar attached to the Clark Dog hot-dog stand. Obviously, that means you can get really soused on the cheap, take ten uneasy steps to the counter and order yourself a chili-cheese dog and a steamy basket of fries, which to you will taste like they were handed down from heaven.
column149: Clark Street Bar Drunken dining is made überconvenient at this dank, sardine can–size bar attached to the Clark Dog hot-dog stand. column7: An odd blast from the recent past, this spacious sports bar—which recently took over the former Players Bar and Grill space—transported us back to the mid-'90s with music videos from groups such as Rusted Root and Blind Melon flickering on a gigantic projection-screen TV. But wait a second: Weren't the beefy, ball-capped boys nodding their heads the same dudes who beat us up in high school for whistling "No Rain" in the hallway?

column7: Really old, really dirty beer steins, as well as posters of Michael Jordan, Mike Ditka and other faded local heroes, adorn the walls of this bar. The room is also home to a stand-up grill serving gyros, Italian sausage and anemic, overboiled hot dogs—just the kind of thing you might want to eat if you have one too many beers.

column7: For those experiencing Cubby withdrawal, here's a place to liquor up while looking longingly at Wrigley Field across the street. During baseball season, you could book one of two private rooms, each with a small bar, 15 seats and five TVs, and order some burgers, corn dogs or pulled-pork sandwiches while watching the game. Or do it now and watch a video of winning games.

column7: We thought we'd seen everything when it came to Irish pubs, but no pub in Chicago is quite as lovely and upscale as this. Rooms like the cozy library (complete with fireplace), tile-floored bar and dining area blend seamlessly into one another, yet maintain their own identities. It's named after the poshest zip code in Dublin; before long, it could transform this area into one of the poshest zips in Chicago.

column7: Place your bets while downing a beer and a Kobe beef burger at this bilevel bar and grill that's so polished you'll forget you're hanging out in an offtrack-betting facility. Ball games take up half of the 200 flat-screen TVs (including a 13-inch at each table). Every other telly is dedicated to horse racing. Channel your inner Bukowski and head upstairs to make your wager with a live teller.

column7: Bars don't seem to do very well in this address. But here's why this one might stick around for a while: $10 bottles of wine on Fridays (oenophiles be warned: You get what you pay for), a long list of hearty sandwiches, the continuation of unlimited bacon on Mondays and an overriding literary theme (a literary open mike happens every Wednesday) that adds a bit of culture to this otherwise all-retail strip of Damen.

column7: The scarlet color scheme and overpriced cocktails of Cherry Red have been replaced by this classy spot's subtle amber tones, comfy leather banquettes and—as its name announces—a comprehensive list of bottled beer. Lots of love is given to highbrow brews, yet the owners seem to be oddly enamored with the Champagne of Beers; bottles of High Life lined up in front of all the light fixtures give the bar a golden glow.

column7: We know, we know: The last thing Chicago needs is another Irish bar. But once inside this sprawling (yet somehow still inviting) space—which has separate areas for eating pub grub, watching the game from the bar and even reading (in the cozy "library")—you just may find yourself wanting more.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77

column7: A bar in a department store may sound like hell (and this place is on the basement floor, so geographically it's pretty close). But this baseball-themed stalwart is crucial this time of year, when the maniacal behavior of frantic shoppers can be endlessly nerve-grating. So sit down, drink and don't stop until you feel ready to go out there again.
column92: Macy's on State Street, 111 N State St, lower level
column144: El: Blue, Red to Washington; Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

column7: It's tough to find an eponymous connection to this place, named for the Lerner and Loewe musical about a mythical Scottish town. But there are other charms to be found: Bartender Dawn will open the peanut bag for you and fix you up with an ice-cold Jäger from the cooler while the rest of the bar buzzes with pool leagues.

column7: Even after the beer garden closes for the season, you'll find plenty of warmth from the friendly clientele at this brick corner bar—not to mention a decent bottled-beer selection: 13 domestics and nine imports (no drafts). Serious steel darters from the Windy City Dart League like to hang at Ricky G's, where playing pool is free and the jukebox offers a serviceable selection of tunes.

column7: Welded to the stools of this cozy corner tap, a loyal contingent of career drinkers elbow up to sip cheap suds and ignore the televised sports. But it's the recreational drinkers lured by killer daily specials that really keep the bar in business. On Saturdays, domestic pitchers are five bucks, and on Sundays during Bears season, you can brave the cold to grill up burgers and brats outside.

column7: Emblazoned with shamrocks, a sign near the front reads "Drink like a champion today." How could you not want to, what with such heartfelt encouragement? With nine drafts, a comfortable U-shaped bar and a popcorn machine to keep you thirsty, you'll find it's easy to do just that. This homey pub also puts out free eats on Bears game days and hosts a trivia contest nearly every Friday.

column7: The exterior looks like just another generic office space, but inside you'll find a clean, rustic room with exposed brick and wood beams, and a genuine steel dartboard that gets plenty of play from the Windy City Steel Darters. The group breaks from practice for the preferred deal of the working-class heroes hanging around the cool pounded-copper bar: a loaded Chicago-style hot dog with fries and a Corona Light for $4.

column7: After a fire destroyed much of this ballyhooed Boystown hangout in early '09, Scarlet has risen from the ashes (literally!) in much improved form. The sepia-toned images, stained glass and gaudy red lighting have been replaced by elegant touches including a 13-foot reupholstered couch, a comfy antique chaise and a glittery vintage disco ball. The rebirth also includes a bit more elbow room—perfect for the elements that remained intact, namely the loyal and adorable bar staff and bustling theme nights like Frat House Thursdays and the First Ward Ball.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

column7: To access this new see-and-be-seen contender, you have to take the elevator (whose color-of-envy glow is no accident) to the eighth floor. We'll admit that the room does have a view—both of the skyline and of the well-heeled, bottle service–seeking clientele—but that's pretty much where this spot stops being distinctive from the bounty of other luxury lounges in River North.

column7: Regulars call this place Roger's, because Roger Patrick's family has run it for the past 56 years. It's clean and comfortable with that lived-in feel, but don't look for flat screens or any of that yuppie nonsense. Instead, there's character in the form of a dusty piano, a brick from Old Comiskey Park on display, and pics of happy-looking regulars grinning around the World Series trophy—something you'll probably never see on the North Side.

column7: When the Hunt Club was revamped (and renamed) a few months ago, the sports-bar feeling was the first thing to go. In its place, three levels of plush, mocha-toned cocktail lounge were installed (the second floor is more suited to dining than the others). But Bears fans need not worry: The plasmas are still here. It's just the sticky floors that left.

column7: Instead of paying the $11 to get into the 94th floor Hancock Observatory, take the bullet-fast elevator up to this 96th floor bar in the sky and drop that cash on a cocktail instead. The decor—a sort of circa-1987 Sharper Image–catalog look—is in dire need of an overhaul, but the panoramic, vertigo-inducing views of the twinkling city at night never get old.

column7: Flo, the octogenarian namesake of this eclectic polka haven, dishes up stories—along with servings of homemade South American soup and pierogi—like a natural raconteur. She's a genuine Chicago character in a place that could legitimately lay claim to "classic" status. Flo's could serve as a set for The Petrified Forest, with its big stage for live bands and karaoke, mixed-up furniture that looks like it came from someone's attic, and ever-present congenial hostess.

column7: When asked if he's the bar's namesake, the grizzled barkeep with the gray beard and ponytail might arch a brow and mutter, in a thick Polish accent, "Depends on who's asking." He'll warm up eventually, as will the drinkers bellied up to the Formica bar laughing at Polish TV shows. They're likely the authors of many "clever" signs, including this gem: roses are red, violets are blue, I'd like to put my penis in you.
column144: El: Orange to Pulaski. Bus: 54B, X54, 62

column7: We're told that the passed-out gentleman stretched over a swivel chair near the bar is "Chuckie." Something tells us this is not an unusual event at this Portage Park dive. A testament to the strength of the drinks? Perhaps. A Bloody Mary here is simply a glass full of vodka with a splash of premade mix. With its posters of scantily clad women (if bra ads qualify as posters), Henryka's gives off the vibe of a preadolescent boy's clubhouse—no secret password needed.

column7: Dirty old men haven't gone the way of peep shows; they've ended up here. On a recent afternoon about a dozen of them lavished attention on the Polish bartender in a skimpy halter top who downs shots with the googly-eyed customers. Competing for attention is Jeopardy! on the TV, which elicits shouted-out answers from the brew crew as it chomps on pretzels served in big bowls. And for those harboring dreams of a better place to be, there's a lotto machine on-site.

column7: Its location inside Evanston's Hotel Orrington may suggest suburban tourist, but yellowing international newspapers plastering the walls give this spacious bar a world-traveler vibe. Despite some bumbling bartending ("Remind me, what's in that again?"), the place is comfy (beware its nap-conducive leather couches), and since unobtrusive jazz is the only background, a bar stool here is the perfect perch from which to recount all your globe-trotting adventures.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: Pace 208, Pace 212

column7: Bargoers in Schiller Park are, it seems, completely oblivious to the luxury sports bar concept. Proof is this bare-bones strip mall spot, where the ball game–dominated TVs aren't the flat-screen variety, and the popular beer isn't microbrewed. In fact, as long as these folks can get in on a game at one of the two coveted pool tables, everyone seems happy to have all extravagance out of sight and out of mind.

column7: If you ask this ill-decorated bar's proprietor (a loud, disagreeable Eastern European man) for the beer selection, he's likely to gruffly point you to the refrigerators at his attached Leland Liquors and tell you to "take a look for yourself." And if you go to the bathroom, beware: He might falsely accuse you of attempting to pocket a beer mug. In other words, come for the cheap booze—not the conversation.

column7: The Bears' season is best expressed by a poster of a three-year-old wearing a Bears sweater and flipping the bird in this conversation-friendly "oasis" in Rogers Park. Swinging saloon doors open into a vast room where a miniature Dale Earnhardt Jr. No. 8 car revolves in a slow orbit over the Formica bar and pretzel rods in big bowls on the bar beckon the adventurous. Tuck a pint, grab a pack of cigs to go and walk a block or so to Giordano's to pick up your nightcap pizza.

column7: Jock hangout or eclectic short-order haven with booze? Beyond the basics, there's a separate room with tables, a fake slot machine and plenty of rabbit cartoons to give the place some "atmosphere."

column7: Inspired by the film that was itself inspired by the original NYC bar, this place is a shotgun marriage of backwoods burlesque and cinematic gloss—a concept that's as authentic as a dive bar at Universal Studios. As expected, we found a contingent of wide-eyed, panting men who ate up the shtick of a pack of scantily clad female drink slingers (the titular coyotes). This, despite the fact that none of the girls could properly pour a Guinness.

column7: No, Virginia, there is no Mrs. Park at this Hilton bar. No tasty Chicago lore, no riveting story—just a made-up marketing moniker, not unlike the sister Hilton Towers property further south that can boast of no authentic Kitty O'Shea. What Mrs. Park's Tavern does offer is ultra-padded barstools, an earth-toned comfort zone with recessed televisions and terrific appetizers to go along with expertly prepared cocktails.

column7: Maybe when it went by the more prosaic name of "The Captain's Deck," this place featured nautical decor and lively pirate types, but these days, the only decorative touches are mirrored beer signs, while the conversation drifts to the pedestrian (four grown men arguing about how to spell Pontiac, for example). We were told by one boozer that 25 years ago, the bar was called Richard Cranium's ("dickhead," get it?). So it may not be the classiest place around, but the beer is cold and cheap, and if you know some good filthy jokes, they'd go over like gangbusters here.
column144: El: Red to Howard. Bus: 49B, 93, 97, Pace 215

column7: There's something for everyone at Hamilton's, so long as you're down with going Greek. Saturday nights feel like a tour down fraternity row, all without having to go door to door and with wallet-friendly specials that complete the package (Coors Lights are $2.75, half-pound cheeseburgers are $3). If a sorority sister passes over a "snowball shot," take it. You'll need one to brave the '80s music Patrick Swayze–esque dance party in the back room.

column7: With its Z-brick walls, cast-iron radiators providing some good Chicago-style heat and a decent-enough pool table, Syrena's has the feel of your best Ukrainian bud's basement lounge. Kick back and enjoy a zimne piwo (cold beer) for under two bucks while sitting at the lacquered bar and play some tunes on the digital jukebox or just soak up the floor show of an extremely diligent bartender whose cleanliness rivals any suburban housewife we know of.

column7: Sometimes it's the little things that win over our cocktail-loving hearts. column149: Bridgeport Inn The smoking ban is evident at this neighborly bar in the form of a gum-filled beer pitcher bearing a sign that reads, trying to quit? have a stick of gum on bridgeport inn. El: Orange to Ashland. Bus: 9, X9, 62. Mon–Fri 9am–2am; Sat 9am–3am; Sun 11am–2am. Average beer: $2.75.
column187: DartsPool tableVideo/pinball games

column7: Keep your chair in the direction of the view (a 15th-floor vantage point with the river, and all the blinking buildings along it, in clear sight) and a cocktail in your hand (despite the name, the "Zentini" actually isn't bad). If you do, you'll find that you're not in the lobby of the Holiday Inn after all—you're out on the town. (Or, at the very least, out over it.)
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156

column7: A Northwest Side Polish hangout where the Okocim runs as cold as the luck of the boozers scratch-off effortssounds typical. Dropped lights, a touch-tunes jukebox, and three flat-screens add a touch of class, but this is still one of those quintessential neighborhood bars where you could disappear into a sea of anonymity.

column7: Morning bars are great for downing an eye-opener, and this Far North spot is where many come to do just that. The bartender says it's been around since 1934, starting out as an ice company (during that buzz-kill Prohibition thing). A photo of one of the ice wagons lends a nice nostalgic touch, and the green Formica bar and green linoleum floor make this place look like a movie set for a director trying to capture a real Chicago Irish bar.
column149: The Wild Rover Morning bars are great for downing an eye-opener, and this Far North spot is where many come to do just that. column7: Curvy banquettes, neon lamps, sleek granite and a tempting martini list are among this Hotel Orrington bar's recent renovations. All would be a lot easier to enjoy without Simon's cranked up criticism on American Idol overpowering the jazz soundtrack. Still, if you can tune out the tube, sink into the plush velvet and split a bottle of vino, you might just find your new Evanston escape.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: Pace 208, Pace 212

column7: It could be the great view of Grant Park, or the menu of diner food that's at your beck and call, or maybe the fact that this bar, attached to the Essex Inn hotel, is a place where you'll be able to sip your drink in peace and quiet. But we can't help but think that part of the reason people come here is that it's one of the only spots around where you can have a drink at 10 am, and nobody will blink an eye.

column7: With a name like this, you'd expect this musty old joint to be a hotbed of blue-collar types, but the laconic bartender says only, "My husband named it that" and then clams up. It's a rather dreary establishment, with the usual worn-out pool table, about 20 barstools, a couple of TVs and nary a draft beer in sight. If you want to nurse the blues without any chipper commentary, this is the place.
column144: El: Orange to Pulaski. Bus: 47, 54B, X54, 62

column7: Your credit card is no good here. The all-night gyros joint and this attached bar speak in dead presidents only. You won't need many for the jukebox, unless you're into mid-'90s hits, or for the dartboard, as every dart is missing its tip. But still, the bartenders and patrons are all smiles. Their hospitality plus the cheeseburgers and Czech Republic beer will have you thanking Zeus for this late-night haunt.

column7: What? Whaaat? We can't hear you over the insanely loud frat-tastic crowd ordering 40-ouncers in paper bags from trucker-capped waitresses, but we're assuming you're asking us what the hell happened to Division. Meet us upstairs (or during the new weekday lunch hours) where we might be able to eat peppery wings and gooey mac and cheese in relative quiet, because it's going to take a bathtub of beer-ritas to get us onto that sidewalk patio.

column7: The standard liquor lineup and menu (eggs and pancakes in the morning, burgers and quesadillas in the evening) won't wow you. But the provisions here are just periphery to heated games of eight-ball going down on a dozen pro-quality tables (hourly rates; free on Saturday). Many of the swaggering stick slingers don't drink at all. But us amateurs, we always play better after a couple of beers.
column144: El: Blue to Grand. Bus: 8 Halsted, 65 Grand

column7: A deserted stretch of Northwest Highway isn't what you would call charming surroundings, but is exactly the kind of stretch that needs a cozy escape. Raised booths flanking a fireplace facilitate intimate conversations over pints of imported ale, while the battered old bar encourages drinking with the friendly, blue-collar crowd. That Guinness getcha hungry? Dig into menu highlights like shepherd's pie.

column7: Think south-of-the-border dive, not Rick's American café. White stucco, dark wood trim and colored lamps are responsible for a shabby hacienda look. Domestic and Mexican bottled beer is cold, and perfect for washing down the usual lineup of tacos and fajitas. Diversions include pool and darts, a few video games and a jukebox.

column7: It's sleepers like this wood-clad corner pub that make bar-hopping worthwhile. Friendly staff and a great beer garden certainly help (well, the latter will when it warms up), but it's the darn good food that seals the deal. Fish tacos and juicy burgers frame the Mexican/American menu, but take a look at what the locals order. Yep, that's ceviche—perfect with whatever draft is on special that night.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 54, X54, 56, 78

column7: In its third incarnation in as many years, this narrow room (which was most recently Fixture) is now just a simple sports bar. There are no beers on tap, and only a handful of televisions. But the neighborhood's residents are apparently so happy to have a place they can pop into every night that they don't seem to mind.

column7: As at the nearby Rainbo Club, the hipness quotient at this less-packed, stripped-down Ukie V stalwart has shot through its nicotine-stained roof, paralleling the changing demographics of the neighborhood. You can still belly up and share cheap suds with a couple of actual Ukrainian expats in the early afternoon, but eager twentysomethings with energy (and hormones) to burn rule the night.
column144: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 49 (24hrs), X49, 50, 70

column7: The bro-tastic meat market that was Hi-Tops is gone, and in its place is this classy Cubs pub that should have sports fans with taste renewing their faith in the Wrigleyville bar scene. Countless flatscreens and a bust of the bar's bespectacled namesake share the woody space with unexpectedly hip-for-a-sports-bar touches like a co-ed sink area and a create-your-own burger menu with options like Wagyu and Tallgrass beef.

column7: We've heard that they're aiming for a frat-boy, sports-bar crowd here during the day, but at night this place seems to be filled with the same skaterish folks who were hanging here when it was still Celebrity. In fact, though the room has been changed (it's a bit brighter), the only major difference seems to be the cocktail list, which now offers gems like the Picklini—Ketel One and pickle juice.

column7: In the realm of Wrigleyville bars, this slightly edgier spot is like the one wayward bro in the group of knuckle-dragging Cubs fans who plays guitar and just happens to have decent taste in film and music. That translates to sports on TV with the sound drowned out by alternative rock, photos of rebellious cultural figures like Jack Nicholson in The Shining, and Bud and Miller suds served up alongside tasty brews by Summit.

column7: There isn't a more accurately named bar in Chicago. The appeal is more complex, though; a jukebox is loaded with classics, the pool table lovingly worn and the room about as low-key as it is tight. Regulars might be curious about new faces, but a few rounds later you'll be old hat. And those rounds will be about as cheap as they come.

column7: You won't find shamrocks anywhere in this polished pub. Unfortunately you probably won't find any compelling reason why the owners didn't stay with the Irish connection its name suggests. Despite much decorative to-do—brand-new hardwood floors, granite bar top, classy stained-glass light fixtures—the menu of thaw-and-serve pub grub and the undertrained staff ("What's a white Russian?") just don't do.

column7: At Purgatory Pizza, Chris Peckat serves both a thin cracker-crust (made with Pabst Blue Ribbon) and a thicker pan crust (which he won't deem deep dish), both of which will be topped with a blend of six cheeses. Situated next to Peckat's barbecue-and-pinup-girls joint, Risque, Purgatory has been decked out with references to Dante's Divine Comedy; Peckat has painted the floor of the place to look like hell and the ceiling to look like heaven.

column7: Even the most crazed commuter won't find it hard to grab some subterranean suds at this Union Station bar. No food is served, but bartenders don't frown upon patrons bellying up with provisions from the adjacent food court.

column7: Darts might seem an antiquated game when compared to Golden Tee, but don't tell that to the dedicated players who gather here for a shot at the dozens of boards (newbies can buy dart supplies at the bar; pros bring their own). column7: Good thing bar owner Michael Finan's pa came from the Emerald Isle, because he knew just which carpentry folks to call on for a custom-built wood bar that evokes an authentic Irish pub feel. Formerly Zephyr's ice cream parlor, the space now sports a deep red exterior, exposed brick, warm lighting, an open door and a friendly staff. Take a comfy booth and some curry chips to go with your Guinness.

Bus: 22 Clark (24hrs), 92 Foster. Mon–Thu 4pm–midnight; Fri, Sat 3pm–2am; Sun 3pm–11pm. Average cocktail: $10.

column7: Normally, sports-crazed drinkers might not look twice at this unpolished Jefferson Park tavern, but once they do, two features will have them hooked on becoming regulars. One, an attached liquor store boasts killer prices and a great selection—good for moving the party home. And two, the oval bar is rimmed with flat screens covering every sport you could want to watch, from the majors to the obscure.
column144: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81, 85, 91

column7: Located on the same block as Perry's and Eppy's, some of the Loop's most popular sandwich spots, Jimmy's doesn't see much daytime action aside from the ball games on the ubiquitous TVs. But when the clock strikes five, the lofty space hums with office drones itching to break the monotony with cocktails and conversation. If you're lucky, you'll run into the eponymous cigar-chomping owner, who's been known to buy the occasional round.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark

column7: True, there is a nice view of the Chicago River from this second-story lounge in the Trump tower. Luckily, the dangerously drinkable housemade punch of strawberries, lime and sparkling rosé helps erase the sticker shock and the crowd.

column7: If you come to this Irish pub at the right time (say, Sunday at 3pm, when an Irish folk group performs), there'll be plenty of room to play darts and plenty of locals to rub shoulders with over a black and tan. Otherwise, you should either be a Northwestern undergrad or be able to keep up with one to fit in with the coed crowd.

column7: When two Irish-American musicians open a pub, you'd better believe they'll pay attention to the tunes. Aside from the Sunday-night traditional Irish jam session, you can pretty much count on sipping your stout to some sort of bagpipe-driven sounds. In nice weather, the massive back patio doubles the capacity, with towering hedges muffling the sounds of Elston Avenue and dishes like classic fish-and-chips, shepherd's pie and slow-cooked corned beef transporting you to the Emerald Isle.
column144: El: Blue to Addison. Bus: 77 Belmont, 152 Addison

column7: "I lost a bet!" the mustachioed bartender at this aptly named bar lamented when complimented on his glittery Supergirl tank top. The winner of said bet could be any of the chatty regulars swigging Miller (the only beer on tap) over a backdrop of random country songs and WWE action on TV. Want to join the family? Sign up for one of the four dart leagues that meet in the back room to mix alcohol with sharp objects.

column7: Picture a cheesy '50s diner reimagined as a smelly dive bar with red vinyl banquettes, an uneven pool table (free on Mondays!) and walls papered with celebrity photos, and you've nailed this place. The service is slow and surly, the drinks taste funny and the music is too loud, but North Park students will escape their dry campus for this place as long as there's nowhere else to drink in the area.

column7: In turning Hey Sushi into a sports bar, the owners did a couple of things: They decked out almost every inch in mahogany, plastered their walls with more plasmas than a Best Buy, and built uncommonly long booths that could easily fit a dozen people each. What they didn't do is install a lot of personality. Guess that's up to the white-hat-wearing, dart-throwing patrons to provide (though we won't hold our breath).

column7: This Polish dive/liquor store somehow manages to look like a brightly painted burger joint decorated with fake flowers and Christmas lights. The jukebox relies heavily on Phil Collins and Eastern Bloc pop, PBR is on tap for $1.25 and there's an entire shelf devoted to $1 shots (mostly schnapps in B-list flavors like root beer). The combo is just the ticket for an end-of-the-night wake-up call that yes, you are wasted.

column7: With a bright red awning and a pizza menu with pies called The Popeye and The Painful, Bricks feels right for grabbing dinner with your parents. But with a wine list that's longer than the drafts, its bar suggests otherwise. Just below street level, the place is built like a cave with low ceilings and exposed concrete walls that are never not cold. If it weren't for the pop-art lithographs or checkerboard tablecloths, you could be drinking in a David Fincher film.

column7: The exterior might scream old-man bar, but this dive is a diamond in the rough. The proximity to both The Cell and the Zhou B Art Center means you might just find a debate at the jukebox between South Side regulars angling for "We Are the Champions" and mop-topped hipsters searching for the new No Age record. But Bernice's welcomes them all with $2 PBRs, assorted imports, local acoustic acts on Saturdays and open mikes every Thursday.
column60: Mon, Wed 3pm–midnight; Thu, Fri 3pm–2am; Sat noon–3am; Sun noon–midnight (closed Tuesdays)

column7: When a sign on a bar's exterior reads "No bra, no panties, come on in!" and the interior resembles a cluttered attic (broken stove in the corner, a collection of Fred Flintstone memorabilia), we're smitten. Be nice, and lovable curmudgeon Ray will flip on the "lights" (a miniature bar-top replica of the Budweiser horses) and the jukebox that holds both Frank Zappa and Dolly Parton. But "Don't ask for nothing too fancy," Ray insists. Enjoy a $2 can of PBR or Old Style instead.

column7: Stepping through the doors of this Portage Park disco is like being magically transported to Warszawa in the early '90s—Polish girls in tight white pants gyrate to Euro dance beats, the scent of Drakkar Noir is in the air, giant disco balls spin and colored lights flash. Jedynka offers an extensive selection of fruity martinis, pricey Champagne and a bottle-keep system for regulars. Once the fog machine starts blasting, you'll have more fun here than at the clubs downtown, even if you don't speak Polish.
column149: Jedynka Stepping through the doors of this Portage Park disco is like being magically transported to Warszawa in the early '90s—Polish girls in tight white pants gyrate to Euro dance beats, the scent of Drakkar Noir is in the air, giant disco balls spin and colored lights flash. Jedynka offers an extensive selection of fruity martinis, pricey Champagne and a bottle-keep system for regulars. Once the fog machine starts blasting, you'll have more fun here than at the clubs downtown, even if you don't speak Polish. 5610 W Diversey Ave at Central Ave (773-889-7171). column7: Wicker Park's only piano bar is also one of its oldest; around since 1998, it opened while area shoppers and sippers were still in school. Karaoke is a big part of the place: the back room bursts with would-be crooners on Friday nights. And on the other nights? Professionals—replete with boas and dirty jokes—show them how it's really done.

column7: This Polish tavern is full of lads drinking Okocim spiked with raspberry syrup and watching soccer on TV, but for an escape, there's a beer garden and a section of loungey leather banquettes divided by fringed curtains where ladies in slinky tops sip Cosmos and appletinis (half price for women on Wednesdays). The service is fantastic, and there's a small menu of Polish-style bar food like borscht and French bread pizza (served traditionally, with ketchup).

column7: The bordello ambience of this Polish martini bar (which has a sister location on Milwaukee Avenue) is inviting on the surface: There's a petunia-lined patio, open-air bistro seating in front and a breezy, red-lit back room with comfortable couches and flowing white drapes. But watery "martinis" (candy-sweet concoctions with names like "Diva" and "Wild Sex") and service that alternates between neglectful and borderline hostile don't beckon us to become regulars.

column7: What sets this vaguely New Orleans–themed place apart from the cluster of cookie-cutter yuppie bars on Southport is the slightly older set; a more low-key, conversation-friendly atmosphere; and a second-floor balcony from which to watch the revelry below—and maybe even sneak a smoke. Decent draft picks, occasional live music, and plenty of outdoor seating add to the appeal.

column7: Locals who grumble about Logan's gentrification need to get over it—stop into this new bar and grill in early evening and the packed rooms of young families with kids in tow, couples watching the game and eclectic groups of friends are proof that the neighborhood needed a catchall. A few warnings, though: The music often edges toward blasting, the presence of beefy bouncerst is weird, and the food pales in comparison to sibling Northside Bar and Grill.

column7: Though the patio section is nice, the view of the skyline here is not stunning enough to skip out just cause it's cold. Especially when you can sit at the stylish indoor bar and get just as much beauty out of the delicious lavender-infused gin fizz cocktail. This fall, check out the new menu from chef Nicole Pederson, the candy-bar trio from pastry chef Toni Roberts and the seasonal cocktails, like the Perfect Storm (Death's Door White Whiskey paired with sweet-and-sour, egg white, and orange dust).

column7: Funny thing about this Navy Pier–area pit stop: Where you'd expect a tourist rip-off, you instead find real value. Forget the blaring TV and dingy decor—a pittance for the unexpected quality.

column7: This aging bachelor's clubhouse is marked by an ancient Coors sign and frequented by a small posse of old men who don't want to be bothered while watching the game. Busts of Elvis and John Wayne share space with pennants for little-known Ohio sports teams, a jukebox full of Ted Nugent and Willie Nelson hits, and a severely limited selection of beers and liquors. This joint may have crossed the line from dive to decrepitude, but who cares when a cocktail costs only $2.50?

Go quick before this one goes the way of Wicker Park.

column7: After Henry Chang got a liquor license for his formerly BYOB eatery Wakamono, he promptly built Boystown's best bar. The intimate space is, like all of Chang's projects, highly stylized, employing lush, floral wallpaper and woodwork the likes of which you've only seen in an opium den. It might be a restaurant bar, but it has a style, vibe—and, thanks to refreshing pear martinis—a taste all its own.

column7: Pity the bars that share a zip code with this impressive newcomer. column7: Not much has changed since the previous tenant, Iggys3, vacated this space: The narrow, dark red room still has a curvy bar; there are tables for indulging in bar grub; and a wall of windows opens up to the street in good weather. column7: Tucked in the shadow of the Morse Red Line tracks, this laid-back neighborhood bar shouldn't be confused with the similarly named spot farther south on Clark. If you visit on an off-night, channel the vibe via the classic country and Southern-rock-packed jukebox.

column7: Out went Bottle Bar, in went the Coach House, and no one inside seems to know or care why or exactly when. Nobody pays attention to the cocktail list either (with its girls'-night-out drinks priced at $8), nor the wines by the glass, nor the fairly extensive beer selection. But even with the majority of patrons clinging to their Miller Lite, there's still the sense that being here—nestled into a warmly lit wooden booth with all those options on hand—is a step up from what came before.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 11, 76

The doors of this 4am bar occasionally stay locked until midnight or later, so save this joint for the end of your bar crawl, or expect to pound on the door for service.

column7: Representing the first-in, last-to-leave motto of Bridgeport's diehard Irish-American population, the Shinnick clan has been slinging beer in this building since the day Prohibition ended. column7: Our bartender (a long-haired film student in a Primus shirt), told us he goes by "PJ" because there are at least three men named Patrick at this bar on any given night. Sure, it's an Irish bar, but it's a tongue-in-cheek one that sells T-shirts that say who's your paddy? Above-average food (oysters on the half shell, fish and chips) and excellent service keep the young clientele coming back for more.

column7: This two-room darts bar seems excessively spacious relative to the sparse clientele on a Saturday night, but it's rumored to draw a big crowd for the blind-draw darts tournament at 9pm on Fridays. Don't expect much excitement during the rest of the week, unless cheap PBR and a Golden Tee golf game is your idea of a good time—which, for many regulars, is exactly that.

column7: At first glance, this place looks like your typical yuppie sports bar, but the vastly male clientele, plum and ochre walls adorned with abstract art, and Kylie Minogue soundtrack reveal it to be Rogers Park's straightest-acting gay bar. It's also dog-friendly and offers a nice selection of retro cocktails like sidecars and lime rickeys.

column7: Tucked in a corner of Red Ivy so hidden that you need to go through the bar and across an alley to get there, this Prohibition-themed room gives off a believable aura of secrecy. And that's the point, really—it was built mainly to house private parties. On the weekends, the space pours from its whiskey-heavy, classic cocktail list for the public—but don't be surprised if, when filled to capacity with Red Ivy's clientele, the vintage feel gets lost.

column7: Yes, there is a Jimbo, and in case you haven't heard, he recently lost the highly publicized legal battle with his landlord and is getting the boot soon. In the meantime, it's business as usual at this Sox Side spot, where little has changed since day one in 1984. Root for the home team, have a plate of Italian sausage and peppers and don't be surprised when your beer costs a buck more on game day.

column7: "Ey Joe, how do you make a Joe Da Bone?" The answer is a pint glass full of Tanqueray, with a splash of grapefruit and cranberry. This is the sort of banter you'll overhear at this neighborhood pub. Funny thing, though: Joe doesn't get to make his specialty often, as the working-class clientele prefers suds to anything close to fruity.

column7: This offering from the owners of Salvatore's has a mellow neighborhood vibe that stands in sharp contrast to the manic Weed Street club scene. column7: You'd think the focus of this bar, which sits on the roof of the Dana Hotel, would be the view. But there's a lot more to distract you—the roaring fire pit, the classic cocktails (curiously served in plastic glasses) and the incredibly short shorts on the servers—so the view pretty much takes a back seat.
column60: Fri 3pm–2am; Sat–Thu 5pm–2am (sometimes closes early on slow weeknights)

column7: From the outside, this place looks like a gallery (which, technically, it partially is). On the inside, it's open and loftlike, with a permanent stage set up for weekly live music. But behind the bar, decked out in a vest and tie, bartender Paul McGee is skillfully making expertly balanced, seasonally-driven cocktails. One sip and there's no doubt that despite everything else going on here, the cocktails are the reason to stick around.

column7: This Hyde Park dive is frequented by only the more adventurous U. of C. students—a sign on the door threatens to deny entrance to those under 23, though it's seldom enforced. The clientele is as diverse as the decor, which includes perfunctory nods to Irish pride, a fresco of the New York skyline, film stills from the 1920s and a jukebox heavy on R&B and soul. Liquor selection is limited, but pitchers are cheap, and there's an order-through window to the pizza and chicken joint next door.

column7: The decor is straight from a Holiday Inn circa 1992, and the clientele consists of the most touristy of tourists. column7: Whereas the Drake Hotel's Palm Court is grand and regal, this lower-level bar is small, intimate and sultry. Some people treat it as a dinner place—there's a perfectly good menu of sandwiches and the like. But we think the live jazz and dimmed lighting lends itself much more to hushed conversation and cocktails than to burgers and beer.

column7: The extraterrestrial theme of this Midway Polish tavern is expressed with marbled blue and purple walls painted with creepy, vaguely anthropomorphic figures that one can only assume are supposed to be alien beings. You'll find pool and foosball tables, but lest you think this is a sports bar, know that the bar is heavily stocked with sweet liqueurs and it's transformed into a Euro dance club on weekends.

column7: At 8:30pm on a Friday night, this recently relocated Cubby bar is the most lit place in Lincoln Park. Bright lights aside, Hi-Tops delivers the proclaimed "sporting nightlife" with flat-screens aplenty, sports photos lining every inch of the walls and a boisterous, though pleasantly mature, crowd. Surprisingly, the black-clad staff makes a decent cocktail too.

column7: Imagine a yuppie sports bar that has been seamlessly converted into a rancho-themed Latin sports bar: Long walls of exposed brick are adorned with folksy wagon wheels, an acoustic guitar and photos of boxers, soccer players and Emilio Zapata. column7: Dueling pianos playing sing-along rock anthems (the Richard Cheese–style rendition of Metallica's "Enter Sandman" was a standout) partnered with buckets of Kool-Aid-flavored booze served with multiple straws makes this national piano-bar chain a big hit for prowling cougars, office parties and easily intoxicated college girls. Can't decide what to order? The cavity-inducing "Sexy Jewish Bartender" tipple is the logical prequel to the "X Boyfriend" cocktail.

column7: "Do you like Vegas music? It's Vegas music night," a patron informed us as we stepped into this slashie that could easily be the set of an early 80's Duran Duran video: mirrored paneling, glittering geometric décor, checkered floors and a multicolored, light-up liquor display. Tom Jones blared out of the speakers as our fetching young bartender mixed up cheap, strong drinks. Just heed the warning on the door, and you'll be fine: "No children, no bikes, no dogs, no selling, no bullshit."

column7: Sometimes known as "Eleanor's" or "that nameless corner bar," this family-run bar and liquor store has been in business for 45 years, catering to neighborhood White Sox fans. It's a bit nondescript (there's no sign or phone number) and markedly quieter than the neighboring Paulie's Place, but the bartenders are entertaining, the drinks are cheap, and there's a charmingly surreal Old Style–themed oil painting on the wall.

column7: Welcome to the jungle? Almost every available surface in this tacky-swank lounge is covered in cheetah or zebra print, down to the leopard shades on the cocktail shaker lamps. Big, cushy red and yellow leatherette booths, and black and white portraits of 90's era starlets round out the décor. The vibe is laid back during the week with a food, fancy coffee drinks and cavity-inducing cocktails; they bring in a DJ for a dance party on the weekends.

column7: The corner location, window neon, "cold beer" cooler and Art Deco bar might lead you to believe this spot is run by a septuagenarian with stories to spare. Investigate further and you'll find an extensive beer list, butter-soft leather booths, brocade wallpaper and hipsters shooting stick in an antler-adorned back room—signs that owners Matt Eisler and Kevin Heisner might be youngsters with expensive taste, but they've set their corner tap on the path toward longevity.

column7: American-flag decor, a pool table and a big U-shaped bar dominate this dive that will most likely never be appropriated by hipsters. It's drunk, cheap and rowdy, and there's an occasional performance by an Elvis impersonator.

column7: The newest attraction at the decades-old Walnut Room is really just a corner of the dining area. Nicer still is the wine list, which touts the bar's pricing policy (the bottles are priced for retail, not restaurant service) and has a staggering number of bottles under $30 to back it up.

column7: It's difficult to know what to expect from a bar that once featured an image of Kermit the Frog on the sign, alongside a collection of beer neons (Kermit has been replaced by a picture of a hand holding a tray, presumably for legal reasons). Our sweet Serbian bartender didn't speak enough English to explain the bizarre namesake, but the in-house APA pool team (which was playing the team from the Cork Lounge) is known as "the Muppets." Well drinks are only $2 on Wednesdays, and it offers espresso and a basic food menu in addition to cocktails and beer.

column7: Smooth-chested twinks and their admirers need not apply—this bar stands out as a prowling ground for old-guard leathermen and bears in a neighborhood otherwise dominated by boozy slushies and dance music. The air is thick with testosterone, chains hang from the ceiling, and the back room shows porn on the weekends. The rest of the week the vibe is mellow, with nightly drink specials and country music from the bartender's iPod. Women be warned—there is no ladies' room, so be prepared to use the stall next to a bank of urinals.

column149: Amp Rock Lounge This subterranean cave of a bar (at the former home of Katacombs) feels like a Disneyland fantasy of an early-'90s rock venue—glossy black walls adorned with scrawled song lyrics, giant glamour shots of icons like Steven Tyler, a glittering bar top and black leather settees paired with tables made from drum heads. No live music or dancing, but the in-house iPod features something like 20,000 songs (though why out of 20,000 you'd choose to play Bon Jovi is beyond us). 1909 N Lincoln Ave at Wisconsin St (312-376-1860). column7: We're not sure if this place evokes an English pub as it's supposed to or if the burgundy booths and ornate carpeting simply evoke the '70s. column7: Situated on a nearly desolate stretch of North Clark, Champions is a bar one does not just stumble into—stumbling out, however, is apparently mandatory. The red glow from several Budweiser signs, the mini bottles of Arbor Mist and the dueling Cherry 96 and Cherry Master 96 video slot machines in this dive dare you to stay for "just one more." The cheap beer and stiff cocktails make a strong case, too.

column7: There is so much kitsch crammed into this little neighborhood spot that you could easily spend your entire visit marveling over a taxidermied boar's head sporting a pair of antlers and a trucker's cap, a full-size statue of an alien wearing Mardi Gras beads, giant fishing lures dangling from the ceiling, and a framed T-shirt that says "Don't show your ass at Bill's Pub." And with specials like $1.50 Old Style drafts on Mondays and Wednesdays, plus bartender Cathy's special Bloody Marys, there are plenty of reasons to stick around.

column7: There's something ironic about a posh stock market–themed bar opening in the midst of an economic crisis, complete with a menu titled "The Wells Street Journal," with bottles of Dom and Cristal listed under "Liquid Assets." The specialty cocktails and upscale bar food like truffle fries with lemon aioli are well executed if you have the cash to burn, and make sure your credit card is ready for one of the buzzed-about booths with tableside beer taps—you might get carried away if you're the one doing the pouring.

column7: True to form, Brando's Speakeasy is anything but what it seems. It's a lounge, but conversation flows more like a neighborhood haunt. Its website promises a martini bar, but the list is mysteriously MIA (most people seem to down beer anyway). The decor and vintage posters throw it back eras, but the karaoke and late-night dance music add modern flair. While it's not Don Vito Corleone meets Al Capone as the name might imply, Brando's is definitely a mash-up.

column7: Fantasy is such a subjective term, isn't it? To some people, this homey corner bar, which fills up with locals wielding pool sticks (and, in some cases, unruly mullets), is just dreamy. column7: There's a lot to love about this vast old-man bar-turned–Logan Square hipster dive: a mouthy bartender who yells abusive endearments like "shut the fuck up!" at regulars, cool music, free popcorn, deals like $2.50 microbrews on Saturdays and $4 PBR pitchers on Monday, Bloody Marys and the Beatles all day on Sunday, a darts league and a "punk bike gang" that meets at the bar on Tuesdays. It's trying to start a pool league as well, so now might be a good time to discover your new favorite bar.

column7: We've heard Little Jim's described as a gay "Cheers" but that's questionable–unless Norm and Cliff are leather daddies into nude male sketches and hard-core porn. During daylight, friendly old bartenders (remember bartender Coach on Cheers?) sling beer to a sparse crowd. On weekend nights, Jim's gets more crowded and seedier than Sam Malone's bed. They may not know your name at Little Jim's, and it's doubtful they'll remember it tomorrow morning either.

column7: This new Pilsen hangout is owned by people who also have their hands in Northside, Black Beetle and Danny's. Nevertheless, it looks nothing like your typical Bucktown bar. And it's this innovative design—coupled with the better-than-average cocktails—that ensures you won't get bored.

column7: Whether or not the guys behind Zentra and Sound-Bar would consider their new retro-futuristic contribution to Division's yuppification a restaurant or a bar, the food (a dozen incarnations of flimsy thin-crusts;, shareable apps like bruschetta and hummus) is clearly designed for the already drunk, so we'll gladly place it in the latter category. column7: This indoor/outdoor bar that popped up alongside Wrigley Field like a fast-growing tumor should be avoided by fans of baseball, bars and watching baseball in bars. A recent post-game visit found all 27 LG flat-screen TVs in the hangar-like party room tuned to a sitcom on the CW, a woman double-fisting cans of Michelob Ultra on the adjacent patio, and security staffers making blustery drunks put out their nine-inch cigars. Incidentally, the only house specialty is the Captain Cubby—the bar's namesake rum and Pepsi in a plastic cup. Suck one down along with a bus-fume chaser, all with a great view of Harry Caray's ass.

column149: The Rockhouse Although it was formerly known as the Rockhouse, nothing at this Lincoln Park "rock" bar has changed but the name. Neon lights, a backlit bar and long black booths lend a sheen of edginess, but the sea of backward baseball caps holding plastic tumblers bobbing along to Oasis covers makes it all feel a bit inauthentic. Go for the decent beer selection on tap, not for a real rock & roll atmosphere. 2624 N Lincoln Ave at Wrightwood Ave (773-871-0205). El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey; Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74, 76. Tue–Fri 7pm–4am; Sat 7pm–5am (closed Sun). Average cocktail: $6.
column187: Live bandsVideo/pinball gamesPool tableLate NightNo stairs to bathroom

column7: Take the River North Rockit, add wasted Cubs fans, and the equation could easily get out of hand. But by comparison to the rest of Wrigleyville, this outgrowth of the Billy Dec empire manages to feel comfortable, inviting and almost, well, classy. Compartmentalization has something to do with it: Families can order Brie-topped Kobe burgers and juicy steak "Pockits" in the first-floor restaurant area, and the rest of the fray can head straight to the pool tables and lounge seats upstairs.

column7: Half-clothed waitresses, expanses of outdoor seating—this multilevel madhouse is as close to South Beach as you're going to get in the West Loop, heavy-hitting crowds included. Looking for something sweet besides all the eye candy? A ball of cotton candy the size of a basketball shows up in a mini grocery cart. Sure, it's goofy, but guilty pleasures usually are.

column7: This loungey, two-story, two-years-in-the-making megabar shoots high with an extensive gastropub menu (that no one's ordering from) and cocktail list (that no one should be ordering from). It's beer, shots and Ed Hardy–bedecked scenesters as far as the eye can see, and that's how Wicker Park likes it.

column7: This neighborhood spot is much livelier than the gray stretch of warehouses and empty lots surrounding it, making it the best (okay, only) place for many blocks to stop in for a drink. The space feels new and not quite broken in yet, but the bartenders already seem at home, chatting with regulars while serving up strong, tasty margaritas and a full menu of mostly average Mexican fare, from so-so enchiladas to decent pico de gallo, available at the bar or in the huge back dining room.

column7: TheWit Hotel's swank rooftop lounge sports a specialty cocktail menu, a well-curated wine list and Mediterranean small plates by former mk chef Todd Stein. Now that the winter chill's kicked in, the outdoor section's closed, but we doubt that'll keep the masses at bay—especially now that the enclosed part of the rooftop plays host to weekend brunch, with offerings like truffled egg toast, "Morning Pizza" and bomboloni.
column144: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State

column7: Welcome to a Celtic version of Hooters, where the waitresses wear even less stretch fabric and TVs broadcast ESPN above every sight line. Traditionalists can scoff at Irish Nachos or Gaelic Chicken, but the burgers and wings are decent, and the bar will mix stout or cider with anything. The secret draw has little to do with Working Joe's Catholic schoolgirl fantasies—it's the second-floor view of the El, a nice angle on the diamond district.
column144: El: Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange, Red, Green to Madison/Wabash

column7: About a dozen Italian wines are available by the glass at this subterranean wine bar, along with 70 by-the-bottle selections spanning the Boot. Small-plates such as a four-cheese panino or mushroom-topped polenta veer from satisfying upward, and the bar recently added new lunch combos (like speck-and-arugula pizza and side salad) to partake in by the fireplace.

column7: The close-up view of the Wrigley Building from the 16th floor of Trump Tower is a sight best appreciated by a local. So it's something of a shame that this outdoor patio draws mostly out-of-towners. Still, if you're looking to throw down $20 for a glass of wine or a (fresh juice–filled, if imbalanced) cocktail, you'd be hard-pressed to find a posher playground.

column7: It's a stroke of genius to open a bar near a place with notorious waits, but to serve burgers across the street from Kuma's—isn't that a little, well, risky? Not if they always come out as well-seasoned as ours, topped with thick slabs of bacon and spread with a chili-garlic aioli that'll almost have you breaking a sweat. And not when they're served with light-as-air, freshly fried chips that beat out Kuma's waffle fries any day. Top 40 tunes and the dearth of draft beers bring the comparisons to a halt, but Square has one thing Kuma's might never have: open seats.

column7: Wall-to-wall male patrons, sports on every TV, nearly a dozen beers on tapthe new pub from the Hamburger Mary's team looks like any other jocktacular sports bar. But breeders will get the vibe rather quickly that locals think of it as a boys-only club. Regardless, beer geeks of all persuasions will wander in to sample the three made-in-house brews—but probably only long enough to put them down and order a glass of their usual.
