column7: Take note: When this Gibsons offshoot calls itself "Lux," it means it in an old-school way. Both the food and space seem to be imported from a simpler era, with dishes like luscious filet mignon "sliders" and crispy, juicy fried chicken. For a clubbier take, check out the recently renovated upstairs lounge, open Friday and Saturday nights only, where all-female DJs spin dance music and mix cocktails, such as the acai liqueur–tinged Ultimat AntiOxidant.

column7: Not so much Irish as Irishish, the latest bar to take advantage of Division's double-wide sidewalks and doubly boisterous crowds has two focal points: a Tiffany-like stained-glass chandelier and 80-ounce, blender-shaped table taps with a block of ice in the middle that keeps booze chilled. The latter of which makes it easy to get doubly wasted.
column144: El: Blue to Division or Damen. Bus: 50, 70

column7: Follow the tamale guy's trail, and you might end up at this low-key, dive-bar-ish hang. The no-frills space is a natural plaidstravaganza thanks to Two Brothers on tap; a back room that plays host to not-bad, no-cover live music; and plenty of space to settle in for the night (and not have to worry about waiting at the door, as at that other hipster-hang up the block). Wednesdays bring dozens of comedians for open-mike nights, and on Record Label Thursdays, local labels spin the music that inspires them. Those nights, buy a piece of merchandise and get a PBR for 1 cent.

column7: Few neighborhoods show the signs of recession quite as viscerally as the South Loop, and this sleek café—in the lobby of a glitzy condo building, of course—sits at the nexus of the stalled mega-projects and half-inhabited high-rises that loom like ghosts from the real-estate-boom-that-wasn't. But inside Little Branch, the scene is much less bleak: An elegant bar lined with tree-trump stools offers a short but well-curated wine and beer list served by some of the friendliest staff around—servers who could use some real-life company.
column144: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 3, 12, 29, 62, 146

column7: We could try to scare you away from the Cedar Hotel. We could tell you the host has arms bigger than our legs. Or that we threw down $14 for a 24-ounce "keepsake" cocktail that came in a plastic cup we most certainly did not want to keep. Or that the "Fifty/50 signatures"—like sliders and burgers—were nothing we'd ever sign our name to. But the people-watching is so damn mesmerizing we might just be back ourselves.

column7: Nothing brings together the hip kids and blue-collar Chicagoans better than cheap alcohol—and this no-frills Logan Square dive across from Fireside Bowl is living proof. Watch as the earnest mustaches of Blackhawks and Sox fans mingle amiably with ironically bearded Black Keys and White Stripes fans. And if that gets dull, just head to the back for a 75-cent game of pool.
column144: El: Blue to California. Bus: 49 (24hrs), X49, 74

column7: When we strolled into this endearingly tacky Latino holdout tucked into a gentrifying residential block, a tipsy twentysomething swiveled his stool our way, raised his hands to the sky and gleefully announced to the four other people in the place, "Finally! You're here." It was drunk talk all right, but this stranger summed up exactly how this bewitching bar makes you feel: like it's been waiting all these years for you to become a regular.

column7: Picnic tables, an outdoor bar and a couple of flat-screens broadcasting the game make the back patio at this Bridgeport sports bar feel like a glorified backyard—that is, a backyard where someone else is manning the grill, turning out better-than-average pub grub, such as artichoke-and-shrimp fritters and hefty burgers on pretzel buns. The only thing missing from the scene is some other people—so Sox fans, bring your own friends.

column7: To go to this glamorously vintage bar and not order chef Jared Van Camp's charcuterie is to miss the point: Finocchiona emanates a deep fennel flavor, the hearty sausage with cornmeal waffles is as gluttonous a brunch plate as we could ever wish for, and the pastrami is a subtle, smoky revelation. So it came as a bit of a surprise that most of the crowd was, indeed, missing the point: They were there to holler at the Bears game. Some yuppies just don't know how good they have it.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 9, 11, 72

column7: The Eat Well Drink Better group closed the Central and opened this supposedly Southern-inspired bar in its place. It's like every other Wrigleyville sports bar (good flat-screens, bad food), except newer and cleaner and generally more pleasant. Perhaps because of those things, it's also less crowded. Whether that's a good thing or a bad thing is up to you.

column7: While you were waiting in line at ROOF, the Renaissance Hotel across the street opened its own swank spot. Bar Novo might not have the rooftop glitz, and the menu (Kobe sliders, prime-rib nachos) reads like a predictable list of upscale bar food, but the cocktails alone—fruity but fresh, strong but balanced—make this place as worthy a destination as its neighbor.

column149: Bar Novo While you were waiting in line at ROOF, the Renaissance Hotel across the street opened its own swank spot. Bar Novo might not have the rooftop glitz, and the menu (Kobe sliders, prime-rib nachos) reads like a predictable list of upscale bar food, but the cocktails alone—fruity but fresh, strong but balanced—make this place as worthy a destination as its neighbor. 1 W Wacker Dr at State St (312-372-7200). El: Brown, Orange, Green, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State/Lake; Blue to Clark/Lake; Red to Lake. Sun–Fri 4pm–2am; Sat 4pm–3am. Average cocktail: $10.
column187: Food served

column7: An Irish pub gone literary, Beckett's hammers home its heritage in every form: Irish-accented waitresses, portraits of the writer Samuel Beckett and lightly battered fish-and-chips and onion rings, all of which can be soaked up in a book-filled nook beneath the writer's watchful gaze.
column149: Beckett's Public House An Irish pub gone literary, Beckett's hammers home its heritage in every form: Irish-accented waitresses, portraits of the writer Samuel Beckett and lightly battered fish-and-chips and onion rings, all of which can be soaked up in a book-filled nook beneath the writer's watchful gaze. 3210 N Lincoln Ave between Melrose St and Belmont Ave (773-880-9620). column7: Faced with increasingly fierce pizza competition, owner Chris Peckat (who also runs Risque Café next door) shuttered Purgatory Pizza and opened this burger bar in its place. Toppings like smoked ham and fried pickles can't hide the fact that the hefty patties are underseasoned—but it's a well-balanced burger even still. The only question is how quickly the neighborhood will catch on.

column7: Chef Rick Spiros took a short hiatus after the last restaurant he cooked at, Mantou Noodle, abruptly closed after no more than a month. Now he's at this West Town lounge, where his food takes a back seat to the two-level, exposed-brick, warehouse-like space and the partyers filling it. So go for the scene, and while you're there, try the fried quail.

column7: Are you prepared to jostle? This is the downtown happy hour to end all downtown happy hours, and you're going to need your elbows to get anywhere near the dozens of craft beers behind the bar. Bar waitresses attempt to holler over the crowd, but the goal of after-work drinking has never been to listen.

column7: In practically any other neighborhood in the city, a nice-looking neighborhood bar (even with slightly above-average food and way-more-attentive-than-average service) won't stand out. But in the chichi West Loop, a welcoming watering hole is actually exactly what the neighborhood needed.
column144: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 56, 124, 125

column7: Although it was formerly known as the Rockhouse, nothing at this Lincoln Park "rock" bar has changed but the name. Neon lights, a backlit bar and long black booths lend a sheen of edginess, but the sea of backward baseball caps holding plastic tumblers bobbing along to Oasis covers makes it all feel a bit inauthentic. Go for the decent beer selection on tap, not for a real rock & roll atmosphere.
column144: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey; Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74, 76

column7: Although the Globe Pub next door quickly established its personality—British, soccer, trivia—Red Brick (which opened earlier this fall as a BYOB and recently received its liquor license) is a bit more schizophrenic. The exposed brick walls are fairly bare except for a bunch of flat-screens, and it's as much a restaurant as a bar. The menu's split between traditional Middle Eastern fare (hummus, falafel) and bar food (fried calamari, pizzas), none of which stands out enough to help determine what exactly the place is going for.
column144: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

column7: If you've ever forgotten to go into a show at Schubas because of how immensely comfortable the front bar is, you might want to consider tying a string around your finger at the Schuba brothers' new restaurant-bar-venue. The design is sleeker and more modern than its Lakeview sibling's, but the fresh-ground burger and the big booths are just as inviting.
column60: Sun–Fri 11am–2am; Sat 11am–3am. During shows, the bar may be available only to ticket holders

column7: There are many reasons to live in Evanston, but unless you're in a Northwestern fraternity, nightlife likely isn't among them. The Cellar, with its slightly staid aesthetic, isn't going to change that, but it does fill a niche: It serves good food (such as salumi sandwiches and sake-steamed mussels, which come from the adjacent Stained Glass kitchen) at a reasonable price after 9pm.
column144: El: Purple to Davis. Metra: Union Pacific N to Evanston (Davis St). Bus: 93, 201, 205

column7: If all you've ever done at Fox & Obel is seek out espelette pepper and single-origin chocolate, you'll be surprised to wander into this new wine bar, where well-heeled older couples linger over wine flights and charcuterie plates. You'd do better to grab a bag of chips off the grocery shelves than order the prepared food here (spinach salad with clashing flavors of funky Brie and mandarin orange, noxiously sweet tofu, oily risotto, unremarkable pizza), but stick with a generous glass of wine and a view of the lake inlet, and it's actually quite nice.
column149: The Atrium Wine Bar If all you've ever done at Fox & Obel is seek out espelette pepper and single-origin chocolate, you'll be surprised to wander into this new wine bar, where well-heeled older couples linger over wine flights and charcuterie plates. column7: After 22 years as Cafe Shino, this Gold Coast stalwart got a makeover and has emerged as a sake lounge, complete with two dozen varieties of rice wine, a private karaoke room, and a menu of otsumami, traditional Japanese small plates (we're fans of the crispy-edged hot-dog bites, plummy baby octopus, spicy salmon hand rolls and tofu-topped udon noodles). For a primer on sake, ask manager Kerry Tamura, who's happy to steer you in the right direction.

column7: Think Wicker Park ain't what it used to be? Yeah, no kidding. Take this bar: It's clean and not the least bit "edgy," and everyone is just soniceand friendlyand chatty. column7: Can a neighborhood bar still attract the neighborhood even if it seems to lack soul? Yes, if you're okay settling for bottom-of-the-barrel bar food. Yes, if you just want to watch sports. Yes, if it's late and there's nothing else around that's open—a likely scenario around these parts. Sound like a place that's not quite worth a trek? Yes, that's why it's for the neighborhood.

El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand; Blue, Green, Pink, Orange to Clark/Lake. Bus: 11, 22, 156. Wed–Fri 10pm–2am; Sat 10pm–3am (closed Sun–Tue). Average cocktail: $14.

column7: New owners closed the spacious, low-key Black Beetle for two weeks of renovations, reopening as—simply—the Beetle. The space itself came out relatively unscathed: Its wood-paneled bar and antique taps retain a sense of authenticity. It's the menu that has moved into new territory, particular this beast called the "Elvis" burger. The patty itself is unseasoned and a tad mushy, but you won't notice: The thing is topped with sweet plantains, awesomely crisp bacon and a dangerously delicious layer of peanut butter. Believe it.
column149: The Beetle New owners closed the spacious, low-key Black Beetle for two weeks of renovations, reopening as—simply—the Beetle. Believe it. 2532 W Chicago Ave at Maplewood Ave (773-384-0701). Bus: 49 (24hrs), X49, 66. Mon–Thu 4pm–2am; Fri, Sun 11:30am–2am; Sat 11:30–3am. Average beer: $5.

column7: If ever there was a cursed space, it's the former Darwin's/Whiskey Road/Chinaski's. The latest inhabitant has done away with the gimmicks and opened the doors onto the sidewalk with a list of decent beers and margaritas. If friendly servers, exposed brick and a diverse jukebox don't cut it, the new owners offer one appeal to gluttonous patrons: the Horseshoe, an open-face sandwich laden with cheese fries.
